review_title: Great culture, hampered by excess management
job_title: Co-Op Student Worker in San Jose, CA
pros: Friendly employees, great culture, lots of good benefits and new products coming out.  The San Jose campus is massive, with just over 50 buildings, and there is always work going on somewhere.  The work environment is also good, and the labs are generally well organized.  They also have free soda/tea/coffee, and you can occasionally find free food by going to various presentations.  There are also two gyms and a daycare center, and provide great benefits to full-time employees.  I accumulated the equivalent of 3.5 weeks PTO per year as a co-op/intern, the same as any regular employee.
cons: There are too many managers and executives, and endless business/technical meetings which do not contribute much (in fact the most useful meetings are the meet&greet because they encourage teamwork, even though they have nothing to do with your job).  Also, the work can be slow and boring at times, and you will not be immune to "burnout" at Cisco.  As a co-op, I received no benefits other than PTO and hourly pay.

review_title: Cisco Still a Good Place to Work
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is a very ethical and humane place to work.  The honest work ethic is exemplified by execs so that they are setting good examples for everyone.  Sr management is well organized and they have long-range plans in place for years to come.  Great opportunities to learn, employess are mostly empowered to do the jobs they need to do and in general are given the necessary resources.  Very process-oreinted company which allows them to be so efficient.
cons: Lots of jobs of all levels and disciplines are moving to India, creating a lot of uncertainty among US-based employees.  While employees generally understand the need to have a global presence, Cisco is sacrificing quality where we stood out in the industry to save money.  In reality, the savings are not that great because there's a lot of rework required to achieve the quality we have always emphasized and worked hard to maintain.  It's very frustrating and disheartenting.

job_title: Systems Engineer, Security Sales in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco remains a challenging environment, driven for excellence. For those able to keep up, you're rewarded well, and surrounded by expert peers, managers, and senior managers committed to your success. Training, lab equipment, peer support are readily available for any assignment or task. The mutual respect and support make Cisco a wonderful place to work. The good pay and excellent benefits add icing to the cake. Working from home is a huge plus! The customers are also very easy to work with because they recognize and respect the level of expertise Cisco engineers bring to the conversation. I love my customers!
cons: The demand for your expertise is constant. You have to know how to delegate responsibility to other teams, and learn how to use your resources, the sales team, and partners to get the job done. Otherwise, you'll end up working 12 hour days constantly. (My colleagues who don't delegate are probably accusing me of only working half a day!)

review_title: Still a good company but not as great as before
job_title: Network Engineer in Toronto, ON
pros:
Flexible work time and place. Good work life balance (... of course it depends on the group you work for).
Pay is not the best but still very competitive
Big company (though on the flip side, it could be a Cons), plenty of resources
Good to get some experience in a big corp (but don't stay there too long)
cons:
Company is too focus on the balance sheet to please the Wall Street. Lack of the vision to be a true technology company. No innovation, no big bets anymore vs the good old days
Smart people left and the current senior management can't provide a vision or direction for the employee, other than constant cost cutting. Regular layoff discourages the people.
Just like any other big corp, some people are not doing there job but stay there while smart people is not rewarded and left with disappointment.
Market is changing faster than it thoughts, big risk to maintain its market shares.
Salary hike is almost none. Hard to get any promotion unless you're very junior.

review_title: Great Place to Work if You Like to be Challenged
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Springfield, VA
pros:
Evolving company with a culture of change, not afraid to make tough changes
Newly revived spirit of innovation and boldness
Great people with a fairly strong desire to collaborate and help out
A lot of lateral career opportunity, which can lead to upward career opportunity
Executive team has great vision and works well as a team
cons:
Culture change has been hard...moving from box selling, to systems, solutions...now to subscription based software solutions.  Vision is good, but the hard part is retooling the sales machine.  Restructuring has been the tool of choice, which has increased employee stress levels and is beginning to dampen the long standing teaming culture
Rapid change and dramatic evolution have come at expense of support solutions With an ever growing/evolving solutions portfolio, with a significant part of that coming through acquisitions, merging and managing the support data/meta data to a standard architecture and set of tools has been a never ending challenge

review_title: Great Culture, Good Vision Tarnished by Constant Layoffs
job_title: Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
CEO Chuck Robbins has clear vision for future
Intelligent acquisitions to accelerate into Cloud / XaaS space
Focus on Customer / Customer Experience is sincere and gaining foothold (vs product / engineering led)
Culture - you're part of something and teams support each other
cons:
Layoffs, called "Limited Restructuring" occur like clock work every 6 - 9 months, usually in September/October and February/March. These have happened consistently in the 6 years I've worked at Cisco. It's demoralizing, erodes the strong culture and instills a sense of inevitability for employees
Limited advancement opportunities to Director, VP and above levels - and, annual layoffs at these levels, not tied to performance, but for "organizational health" (ie balancing the senior positions to early in career and junior employees).

job_title: Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Salaries catching up to the rest of high tech though they expect you to work two jobs at once
company results getting better gives us hope that they will get out of the frantic mode.
cons: continuous crunch time for the  past 5 years is wearing  people thin. you are expected to work evenings, early mornings, sunday night. You are motivated to do this for crunch time once in a while but this is one continuous crunch time. The company is distressed and with the recent good results they are patting themselves on the back and asking for more. People are voting with their feet and walking out to new jobs. Req for open jobs go unfilled. There is an air of tyranny in the atmosphere and employees that can walk are fed up. And what makes it worse is an air of condescending attitude towards anyone that has not been with the company from the golden days with the old hands full of the not invented here syndrome and taking care of their buddies regardless of performance or ability. It is a Babel of cultures and sometimes very hard to make a change and do the right thing.

review_title: Cisco - great place to work, if you don't get impacted...
job_title: Program Manager in Amsterdam
pros:
- Many possibilities, different teams, different positions, working for Cisco allows you to explore different types of roles and team cultures without needing to leave the company
- Flexible working, from home, from another country, from wherever you are. Cisco fully encourages the "work from wherever, whenever" as long as you get your stuff done. Good setup at home including video units, secured routers, etc
cons:
- The annual re-org seems to have become a trend. Most people you speak to don't expect to still be there by the time retirement age hits
- Working in a more expensive European country means you'll face fierce competition for your job coming from cheaper countries.
- Working for one team vs another can have a huge impact on your softer benefits like education or bonus. A lot depends on your teams' management. Where one manager will tell you "NO" on something you ask for, working for another manager might very well result in a "YES" to the very same thing. As a result, employee equality is often compromised.

review_title: Great place to learn, not a place to stay
job_title: IT Director in San Jose, CA
pros: Worked there for over 10 years. They have a great flexible working schedule in most job roles. Lots of learning opportunities. Global company with a global presence. Great place to start a career right out of college.
cons: The company values management. Individual contributors who do most of the work are not valued, are given no equity, and promotions are few and far between. They'll tell you there is no money for raises for hard working individual contributor, then a month later several vice presidents will be promoted to senior vice president. This happened over and over when Chambers was CEO. Layoffs are constant (called limited restructurings). In their IT department, where I spent part of my time, they push out anyone who tries to innovate or disrupt. The entire IT organization is run by the same people who've been there since 2000. The broken reward system made it impossible for me to keep my best workers.

review_title: Strategy and Execution is in a constantly in flux
job_title: Engagement Manager
pros:
Decent Pay
Good 401k match at 4.5%, vests 100% upon match
Some of the best products for collaboration, data center
Flex time and telecommuting is the norm
cons:
Cisco continues to cut jobs through massive layoffs (5500 direct) and (another 8500 through early retirement). Some were double CCIE's and many were CCIE's. This does not show value in employee skills 
No strategy for IoT
Executive Management does a poor job communicating strategy
Internal transfers are difficult
Services margins are too high to build an IoT line of business
Sync-ups has replaced a poor personnel performance ranking system, but few managers follow,the policy on conducting the sync ups.

job_title: Marketing Manager in Feltham, England
pros: Innovative company that trusts their employees and gives them space to shine.  You get from Cisco what you put in. You will find great opportunities but they would be just handed to you, you need to build your network and go looking for it. If you do, there's a lot to gain! Cisco allows you to work from home or from any office you like (except for very few office-based positions), it  offers great compensation and benefits, discounts, peer-to-peer reward scheme, amazing offices with good restaurants and lots of perks like massage chairs and nap pods, gym, allows time off for volunteering, good pension contribution. For the ladies, there's also a lot of investment from the company to bring more women into technology and to develop the next generation of female leaders.  There's also a good maternity leave and there is even a nursery at the headquarters
cons: Flexible working has its pros and cons. Because people come and go from the office at any day or time they like and can work remotely, you may feel a bit isolated at times.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
CULTURE
-------------
Strong and evolving, focused on engineering quality and outcomes

TECH
--------
On-premise codebases suffer due to legacy, but command a massive customer base and hence continuously refactored and churned with new features. High focus on engineering practices, quality and automation. Solid architectures.

Cloud services and components are new, employ relatively latest paradigms, but lack any significant customer base.

LEADERSHIP
-----------------
Passionate senior management that puts the interests of the org and people above all else. Encourages feedback, ideas and initiatives. Ready to experiment with people, processes and perspectives.

ORG STRUCTURE
------------------------
Relatively flat and transparent, dynamic structures that rapidly evolve to solve problems.

ENGINEERS
----------------
Rock-solid technical leaders, a good percentage of expertise among engineers makes this a good place to work and learn. 

INNOVATION
------------------
General impetus and encouragement to any innovation at all levels. Hacking is highly encouraged.

FUN + BENEFITS
----------------------
Engineers get to use best in hardware, equipments and infrastructure
Relaxed, fun and alive work atmosphere while also being super-intense and engaging
Amazing, huge campus here in Bangalore
cons: Lack of vision at product management - On one hand, the on-premise portfolio is struggling to re-invent and be competitive among newly emerging competition. On the other hand, the cloud strategy and services have turned out to be unimpressive, at least until now. Product Management at all levels is unable to figure this out yet.

job_title: Solutions Architect in Melbourne
pros: For a big, long established tech firm Cisco have done a great job at keeping in front of technology trends meaning is always new technology to work on and a good vibe around the company that has done very well by most measures across 20 years which is a pretty impressive achievement.
cons:
Promotion can be slow. This is largely because churn is low, its common to see senior team members with 15 - 20 years service.  That shows its a great place to work but means new opportunities at the top rarely open up and are hotly contested when they do. 

Regular redundancies and re-org's run through the company. Is pretty well 100% of the time either adjusting to a re-org or learning about the ever more complicated org structure about to be deployed.

review_title: Cisco Marketing Intern: Best Job Ever
job_title: Marketing Analyst Intern in San Jose, CA
pros: Collaborative work environment. Everyone loves what they do and as a result, they work as a cohesive unit. Great leadership, not too much of a heirarchy. If you have a good idea, then you can take it to the top. Very responsible socially too. A lot of community service opportunities and they definitely care about others. This is not any other greedy corporation. It's a wonderful place where you can grow and develop rapport with fellow employees. I loved my time there and I hope that you will consider it to be one of your top choices as well. Good luck!
cons: I really don't think there's anything wrong with Cisco. I'd say the only probably is that it is so large, that it is hard to find your way around the company. But that's the case with any other company of this size as well. I would suggest that they strengthen their internal communications, otherwise things will get lost in translation. They're also placing a great emphasis on the future, but if these projections turn out to be remarkably inaccurate, this could be very detrimental to the company and your long term future. So theres' a risk involved, as is the case with most tech companies

review_title: Better on paper than in reality
job_title: in Atlanta, GA
pros: Cisco is innovative and profitable. It continues to grow through acquisitions and is continually expanding its "footprint" of products and services. It is considered by some to be one of the best places to work. It offers an exceedingly diverse workforce population in terms of nationalities (primarily Asian and Indian); the compensation and benefits are competitive; there are learning and development opportunities.
cons: Although the company talks about work/life balance, there is an expectation of 24/7 availability,  Not surprisingly, there is an extremely heavy emphasis on the use of techology for all purposes (meetings, communication, getting the job done) such that there is limited support offered by people. Each employee is expected to be self-supporting in all areas, including administrative. There is an inordinate number of meetings during which much is discussed but often with little definitive outcome. Participants like to discuss past accomplishments. Finally, as one would expect, the size and decentralized aspect of the company make it difficult to identify and navigate among departments and people. Thus, it takes longer than necessary to accomplish relatively small tasks and can be very frustrating.

review_title: Cisco is a big monopoly and it is managed badly from top to bottom.
job_title: Business Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: They have a lot of money, and that gets them through a lot of bad management. Record profit translates into laying off 5,000 people. Get some skills here and then go work for a company where your talent will mean something.
cons: Cisco is a big monopoly and it is managed badly, but it does not matter because they leverage their monopoly to make money. The internet would be better if the company was broken up into 12 companies based on their monopolies in so many areas. They are a classic example of a place that at one time was great to work for and each year it goes down hill like IBM and Microsoft. I had two alcoholic middle managers that did not care about my group or understand business. You will be a just a number at this company. Cisco's vision is to maintain there existing monopolies and buy start ups that challenge them.

review_title: Wonderful company to start and grow with
job_title: Systems Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Depending on your team and your customer(s), you will have very different experiences. I've been lucky enough to come in through their new hire program (CSAP - Cisco Sales Associates Program) and consistently be part of very young, energetic teams. I love the aggressiveness and go-getter mentality prevalent within my team, and my organization as a whole. It matches very well with the energy we experience working with our customers in Silicon Valley. I've also had great luck with managers -- they are caring and involved, notice the work you as an individual contributor are putting in, and really show their appreciation.
cons: Cisco is of course a very large company, and with it comes the extensive red tape that makes significant change difficult. So, although you get incredible stability and perks working with such a well established organization, it is also very hard to instigate change. Trying to change how a particular product platform works or add significant feature improvements across multiple platforms will take a very long time.

job_title: Low Level Engineer Doing the Work in Southampton, England
pros:
Good pay and benefits. 
Can be interesting work in the write department. 
Top level and bottom level workers are good at what they do.
If you have good social skills and want to climb up the ladder then there are good opportunities if your face fits.
cons:
Lower management is a joke and more like a boys club. 
Priorities are themselves, then the project then if there is any time/energy left their staff.
They lack of knowledge on how to handle exceptional engineers/people, the ones who come with side effects, so good is the best they will get/keep.
The top people at the bottom (i.e. the engineers doing the work) often do not have great social skills and management can't handle them no matter how good they are at their job of for the project..
You have to spend more time looking after your career than doing the job if you want to climb, it's not a place to survive at the bottom level for long. If you want to stay hand's on then Cisco isn't for you no matter how good you are.

job_title: Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
You get  to work on the good software stack and with smart people.
Cisco encourages to take up training on courses/technologies of your interest.
You can have a good learning curve.
cons:
The things you hear about the company is not the same inside.
The culture is deteriorating, poor work life balance, you are even asked to work on weekends and no comp offs given if the decision doesn't come from upper management.
Too high work pressure , there is no action being taken to increase the resource pool to meet the demand.
Less rewards or appreciation even when you put extra effort. It is taken for granted that you were bound to work long hours. 
Due to high demanding work load , Managers fail to set goals or proper road map for your career development.
Most of your colleague  are busy and it become difficult to approach them when you are struck and  documentation is also poor and literally no ramp up strategy.
When you join in, you sure gonna feel frustrated and start feeling probably you are in wrong place.

review_title: Cisco is a good place for Jr. Level people to start their career
job_title: Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Locally, it is one of the highest paid company.  It is really the only game in town.  Hours are flexible with a lot rich company amenities like free soft drinks and bottled water. Still paying a bonus --- for now.
This is a very good place for out of college people - lots of security and compensation for Jr. level people.
cons:
Cisco is a very SJ centric company.  All major decisions are made out of SJ.  RTP is a staff augmentation to SJ with most people are reporting to managers/directors in SJ.
Visibility is one of the biggest factor for promotion and not performance.
Reward the dive and catch more than sound and steady management.
Lack a good portfolio management process causing too many projects/initiatives with questionable values and results.
Artificial time bounded project

review_title: Company still too top heavy, but with some great employees
job_title: Senior Operations Manager in London, England
pros: There are some wonderful employees at Cisco, and generally a very strong work ethic.  Most people are genuinely trying to do their best for the company.  There is a good opportunity to work globally and certainly to experience interaction with people from around the world, using virtual collaboration tools.
cons: Weak HR means that managers deal with an antiquated performance management process (based on a 15 year old GE model); lots of unhealthy politics at the SVP level and too many Directors sitting pretty due to tenure; recent RIFs have taken a slice out of the workforce, but not out of the much more expensive layers of the organisation.

job_title: Senior Content Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Cisco has the perfect balance of innovation, from a technical perspective, and established business practices with a strong customer base. A primary benefit to employees is a reasonable pace. It's possible to do excellent work without sacrificing one's personal goals and the work environment is definitely more collaborative than competitive. An additional benefit is the ability to move about the company to work on different products and projects. 
The employee population is remarkably diverse and both the executive leadership and HR underscore the value of inclusion and collaboration (diversity) in both it's composition and everything it says and does. Cisco takes diversity very, very seriously.
Deep support for working remotely is absolutely outstanding! We're able to draw  talent from all over the world instead of limiting ourselves to only those people who are willing to live in or near Silicon Valley.
cons: The overall culture isn't quite as tech intensive as the culture I've experienced at major software  and services companies such as Microsoft.  At other companies for example, demos of products in development were a critical component of any meeting. At Cisco we tend to focus on the bigger business picture.

job_title: Architect in San Jose, CA
pros: Good salary, good benefits, a great place to work remotely
cons: Ridiculous levels of overhead--pre-pre approval for even simple expenses like a mouse.  Absolutely no approvals for travel of any kind.  Ditto there is absolutely no budget for training at all, even if the courses are internally offered.  You may grow distant from the company/fellow employees etc over time since you'll never actually see any of them.  Managers are promoted past their level of competence.   Simple things like submitting a fix for a bug have masses of overhead.  They change management tools constantly so you'll probably have to update information in multiple places about the same thing.  Lots of the help on the web is archaic and simply results in 404's.  IT support is generally pretty bad too.  The meetings that are held are mostly focused on sales and pitching the information appropriate to sales staff.  Customer support relies on direct connection with engineers who as a result have to be available long hours/weekends with some frequency.

review_title: Safe and flexible company, but headed off the path
job_title: Communications Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Cisco has great resources for working from anywhere - the technology and tools are extremely supportive with real BYOD on campus and great virtual meeting tools, all from the Company's own portfolio of course

You will also be working among some of the best professionals anywhere and will learn many best practices that you can take anywhere.
cons:
The top leaders have floundered with their strategy and as such have lost any momentum for growth - do not expect to make big money with stock growth, as this is a mature company (despite being in "high tech").

Managers are generally inept - the entire organization is very "political" and requires you to spend more time managing upward and sideways than actually getting things done for the business. Be prepared to be coached on opportunities to be "visible"

If you are lucky enough to grab a big, visible project and if you spend a lot of time managing up, you might get one of the very rare promotions allocated for your organization. A good strategy for new hires is to negotiate for the biggest salary and title you can.

job_title: Technical Leader II in Raleigh, NC
pros: Challenging work, freedom to solve problems, good benefits, and pay is very competitive.
cons: Constant cycle of lay-offs.  New hiring is heavily focused on college grads, while lay-offs tend to focus on higher salary experienced workers.  Cisco uses a lot of somewhat unskilled contractors to fill the voids left by lay-offs, leaving some business units in near chaos.  Cisco is top-heavy in management.  There seems to be a line drawn between first line managers and the management team above, where the folks in the trenches making things happen don't really know what that upper layer of management is doing.  Then there's a slew of Program Managers that seem to have no other responsibility other than to feed information to upper management.  Employees in the trenches question the value being provided by upper management.

review_title: Cisco: Stay profitable/Support "what you call" your most valuable resource
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in Milpitas, CA
pros: Interesting technology and intelligent colleagues make unpleasant working conditions *almost* tolerable (though not quite).
cons:
Congested, noisy work areas
Little to no support for writers working remotely. Overcrowded freeways  guarantee a 1.5 to 2 hour round trip commute from my home (10 miles from the Milpitas campus where I worked). Factor in the after-hours conference calls and last-minute deliveries, Cisco gets approximately 10-20 hours free in addition to the 40-hour weekly salary the company pays exempt employees.

job_title: Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
- Cisco Bangalore campus has world level best amenities and facilities.
- Work life balance is good.
- You are open to take training on any new technologies coming in.
cons:
There are many.. let me share few of them:
- If you are joining Cisco Service Provider India, do not expect hike/raise for at least next couple of years. People do not get hike for years(3-4 years).. Promotion is too hard to get.. you need to perform like best in team for 3-4 years continuously to get it..
- There are very less teams where you gain a good domain knowledge while working.. else everywhere just sustenance work.
- Most of managers do not care of your learning/development, their main concern is just to get the bugs fixed on time. So most of them follow the push mechanism to get the work done.
- You wont find any motivation to work. No one talks about new technologies and year by year you will loose confidence in yourself.. as you will work hard even then you wont get any appraisal..
- Most important thing, engineers are treated as slaves. Till the time they need you, you will be treated well and when they don't need you they will find a better slave and dump you..

review_title: Love people & technology? Love where you work
job_title: Technical Solutions Specialist in London, England
pros:
If you love people and technology - Cisco is an excellent place to start, grow and extend into a role. 
CSAP (Cisco Sales Associate Program) - is a global accelerated program designed for you to learn and propel your career at Cisco. You are given the opportunity to gain professional certifications, travel and create worldwide friendship. This year long program was the perfect way for to start my career at Cisco. 
Cisco will allow you to move to find a role to suit you and managers are supportive for you progressing in your career path.
There is a reason why #lovewhereyouwork and #wearecisco go hand in hand, flexible working is encouraged to help you work how and when suits you, Fun fund is what happens every few months to bond and have fun with your team mates.
If people culture is something you are looking for in your career, Cisco is where you will be made to feel at home with a new Cisco Family.
cons: As with any big company; restructuring, politics and change can majorly impact careers but this is not unique to Cisco. Change in technology, change in workplaces will happen in any field this is not something to fear.

job_title: Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Got a better job in two weeks
cons: Got laid off while on PTO

job_title: Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Learn a lot in a very little time. If you want to know about data communications business, this is the place. If you can survive the grind in the first year, you tend to do well anywhere in the long run. Other than P&G this is the place to learn about marketing and sales. The only place in fact in high tech. I learn't more at work than at business school.
cons: In a large company and particularly in large business units it is inevitable to have  mediocre politicians, who sullify an otherwise excellent atmosphere. Your competency may not always count. Sometimes the mid level leaders can be absolute idiots as well, so you have to watch your back even if you are competent and doing everything right. In other words do your stuff well, but learn basics of being a politician and always watch out for mediocre idiots, they could potentially damage your career at CSCO.

review_title: Stable job, Great Work Culture, Good employee benefits
job_title: Software Engineer III in Bangalore
pros:
The work culture driven by mid- and lower management is extremely good & healthy. They are very supportive of employees' career growth, work-life balance and project timelines. There are silos which work in an extremely aggressive start-up mode (with their own benefits), but this is more an exception than the norm. The flexibility given to employees in terms of telecommuting and work-from-home are very encouraging - cab services, VPN on laptops, home broadband reimbursement etc. 

The Cisco India campus has blossomed over time into a nice cocoon of sorts. It has multiple food cafeterias, a big health centre, a state-of-the-art medical centre and several games / sports facilities (basketball, badminton, cricket, table-tennis, carrom, Foosball, gaming arcades, massage chairs)!! The company has a great healthcare plan for employees and their families, including free annual health checkups.
cons:
Even though the management harps about Innovation from India, some groups / teams are working on maintenance-only projects. 

If you're a programmer who loves to work on bleeding-edge technologies and likes (re-)designing entire new products, this may seem a boring place. Lots of Cisco's products work on legacy technologies and it is impossible to re-write them when they earn billions of dollars for the company.

review_title: 10 Years at Cisco in both Sales and Sales Operations Roles
job_title: Program Manager in Reston, VA
pros: Cisco emphasizes work/life balance and this is honored in all roles I've held with the exception of sales. Medical benefits are very good, 401K options are comparable to other companies.  Other perks like tuition reimbursement are above average. Cisco IT is very good about maintaining the latest technologies and tools to do you job. (ie: BYOD for mobile devices and virtual office setups to support remote workers.)
cons: I've witnessed 3 major layoffs since joining the company in 2004 and at least half a dozen re-orgs within Sales Operations.  Salaries are competitive when you first join the company, but it's difficult to advance due to HR policies and bureaucracy.  In my case, it has been a lack of job role hierarchy and descriptions on the part of HR that has prevented me from continuing to advance.  Cisco struggles to attract millennials and the workforce is aging.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros: Cisco is a huge company, as such there are lots and lots of different initiatives and opportunities for employees, from volunteering to training courses, employees are really encouraged to take the lead and shape their career.
cons:
The downsides are mainly due to the current uncertainty caused by unprecedented times, speed at which markets and technologies need to evolve, for such a large company tough actions have to be taken. 
Currently we are undergoing a transformation, but this causes frequent reductions in the workforce, change of strategy and its a struggle to feel part of the cisco family that it is often advertised.

review_title: The perfect company for cool dorks.
job_title: Systems Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Cisco is a leader across many different sub-industries within IT: routing, switching, storage, VoIP, wireless, optical, application acceleration, etc. which allows sales engineers to gain a wide breadth of knowledge and exposure across many different technologies and products. Working with Cisco is very fast paced and you get to play with cutting edge technology that has not been released to the mainstream public yet. Cisco sales managers do no micromanage; they give their employees all the freedom and resources needed to get their job done.
cons:
If you don't love electronics or gadgets or computers, you will be lost. You have to love technology to succeed or you will be too overwhelmed. 

When working in sales where customer satisfaction is paramount, sometimes this means you have to make yourself available during non-standard working hours.

Also, because attrition within Cisco is minimal, promotions to management positions within Cisco might be harder to obtain because few managers want to leave.

review_title: Getting worse and worse. Cisco is trying to transform, but forgetting the employees in the process.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: The people are awesome, passionate, and eager to solve problems when they're not burnt out. Cisco has a strong culture and value system.
cons:
Personal growth, the benefits are declining year over year in major ways. It's obvious the group in charge of US Benefits is pushing employees to high deductible healthcare plans, with lesser benefits than in the past.
Many people are burned out after 4 years straight of "limited restructurings", aka Layoffs. It is a bit like the Hunger Games here. While those who are LR'd have fantastic packages, those who are left are forced to shoulder the additional workload, without increased pay or benefits.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Bangalore
pros:
Note: This is about Cisco Video Technologies.
It was OK before Cisco acquisition at least in terms of the limited technology they work on.
It had the charm of a 'small' company before.
cons:
Note: This is about Cisco Video Technologies.
1. Heavy Politics, favoritism.

job_title: Intern Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Great Benefits
High Pay
Work from home
Friendly People
cons:
Lack of control over anything that you do. "Architect" teams in the marketing department make all decisions and promises without consulting the engineers. Due to management structure, these decisions cannot be appealed.

As an intern, I was put on a team that was in no way prepared to take on an intern. They had great difficulty giving me anything to do. The one real project I had took me 3 weeks, after that, despite asking for more work I was barely given anything to do.

My entire team was very upset with management and the decisions being made, but was powerless to even voice these opinions.

Satellite locations get overlooked a lot. You are a second class employee if you're anywhere but San Jose.

I saw multiple instances of people being hired as developers and then being placed into a sysadmin job under the guise of devopts.

Oh yeah, and they're laying off 20% of their workforce.

review_title: A really great place to work
job_title: in London, England
pros: Cisco is incredibly collaborative and there's a real sense of community and inclusion.  There are lots of amazing people working here and you're really encouraged to bring your true and full self to work.  There's lots of opportunity to develop yourself and to play to your strengths.  The Cisco People Deal sets out clearly what is expected of me and what I can expect in return from Cisco.  Cisco has a culture of trust - I am trusted to deliver - I work hard and am given the autonomy and responsibility to do my job and to be creative and innovative.  In return I get a thank you, lots of flexibility (both Time and Location), great Rewards and Benefits, and I'm treated fairly and with respect.  I love that Cisco focuses on giving back and every employee is encouraged to do the same :)
cons: It's a large organisation so it can take a little longer to get some things done.

job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in London, England
pros:
- Great for Grads as a starting point
- Nice Staff at technical level
-initially supportive
cons:
- CoE system will promise you a promotion if you do X and Y. Only when i handed in my notice did i find out they had promised 10 people in the same CoE a promotion with only 1 spot availible, despite it being oversure for all of them

- Management do not give a damn about technical staff. Most technical staff move over to presales

- You can be forced out of your area of expertise then expected to start from scratch. For example Getting a second CCIE when you already have one with no training allowance or lab kit. 

- If you are technical you get no credit. Walk a customer to sales that then results in a multi-million dollar deal? You won't even get a thank you on a company quarterly meeting, the presales guy that sat in two meetings does though

job_title: Systems Engineering Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: I love the people that I work with - they support me and challenge me every single day!  I also love that Cisco places such importance on giving back to the community.  We are encouraged to give back with our time, and we even get 5 days of "giving back" time every year, in addition to regular time off.  I also love that no matter my passion, or how I want to grow, there is a role for that at Cisco.   I also love that I have had the chance to take a TON of leadership training throughout my career.  There have been opportunities specific to being a woman - how to navigate an industry where I am a minority, and helpful tips on managing my career, and opportunities available to all, to grow as a team leader, a strategic leader, and as a person.
cons: Every role has his ups and downs, as does every company.  But what I have found is that we work through them all as a team and as an entire company.  We all have to do our part, and we never lose alone, because we have the whole Cisco team behind us.

review_title: Good Company, Very top heavy management that Gets in the way
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Overall a good company. Has a lot of good benefits. Very flexible in working remote or from home. ESPP is about up to 10% of your salary. 401k Matching is 4.5% which is vested immediately. Bonus at mid year and end of Fiscal year. Each department is a bit different. Some work crazy hours while others are very laid back and are hardly in the office. I always looked at Cisco as a company for people that have a family as it provides a great work life balance. If you are new or early in your career, there are better companies to get more experience.
cons:
Get rid of most of the management. Too much politics and favoritism going on. People are just promoting their buddies and then wonder why all the good employees are leaving. 

Need to implement better salary increases. Some people can go on for years without seeing a single increase.

review_title: Love working with great people and products
job_title: Principal Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
* People: Great people to work with. By far the most amazing team I have worked with. By the way, I had left Cisco and, after 1 year, I came back because I loved working with my current group. The culture shift is refreshing. Be a part of it.

* Products: Amazing range of products. And all of them are being inter-connected with one another leading to endless possibilities

* Pace: Company is moving at light speed in developing/acquiring/integrating new technologies in networking and other areas. If you are in the right group, the pace is blinding (in a positive way)
cons:
* There are still some teams with very slow pace and not eager to change. But the culture is changing positively

* No free food. We have free snacks though. But honestly, free-food is over-rated!

review_title: Line Manager Culture means Management unaware of what happens in teams
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Good coffee in the breakrooms.   Free popcorn.  Nice campus.   Remote chance of getting into good teams with competent managers.  But not likely.  Nice big buildings.   Big parking lot.
cons: Ignorant and highly bureaucratic line-engineering organisation, which allows for dysfunctional team dynamic, constant turnover and stress.   Little to no innovation in products (Skype/Microsoft perfectly positioned to obliterate this "Telepresence" business with easier to use and less expensive products).  Creativity and innovation not valued, this company is a bone mill all about filling out forms.

review_title: If you don't want to be overworked and underpaid, stay away. Good place to start your career though.
job_title: Senior Manager in Diegem
pros: Good place to start your career and to gain corporate experience. Benefits are slightly above average if you land the right position and the environment is extremely flexible when it comes to working hours.
cons: It is an extremely political environment and individual contributors get their careers affected when they don't follow the game, sometimes without even realizing it. Executive leadership has developed this huge EGO that makes it practically impossible for the employee's feedback to be taken into consideration and make effective changes.

review_title: Choice program has an achilles heel
job_title: Software Engineer in Richardson, TX
pros: In the ios group for my internship at hq, it went very well.  Had a good manager.  Worked with people that great to work with.
cons: Other location (Richardson for me) may be different.  For my full time offer I chose Richardson for a combination of cost of living and family living in the area.  All the good of the internship, the full time was opposite.  My manager had described his group as having what I wanted, but it wasn't close.  Not sure who to talk to, I spoke with the local choice program rep and was directed to another manager that just told I had to have been mistaken of the group I chose.  So I found another job and left, just before I left I found out that I should have talked to normal HR and not anyone from the choice program about the false advertising of my group

review_title: Still good but best days are behind it
job_title: Program Manager in Durham, NC
pros: Lots of smart people that are mostly, very hard working. Good work/life balance (for most) with plenty of tools to help get that done. Pretty good benefits. Good lateral move possibilities.
cons:
Stock options are worthless. Raises are few and far between and RSU (Reserve Stock Units) and cash awards are becoming more and more rare. Company is slowly evolving into IBM; people are commodities, everything is   assessed on cost/value and layoffs are a regular occurrence. Can't develop software products...horrible. 

Company is having a hard time realizing it isn't in a high margin hardware, "nobody ever gets fired for buying Cisco" kind of company. This is a big old supertanker and it takes FOREVER for it to change direction. Unfortunately most of its competition are in super fast speedboats.

review_title: Not such a great employer anymore
job_title: Systems Engineer in London, England
pros: Flexibility with work schedule and working from home is the biggest reason why people remain in Cisco.  Really good benefit package and you work with some great people and talent.
cons: Switching off from work when you finish whether it's the end of the day or during your time off.  Management is frustrating, they just don't seem to see you as a person and recognize the employees that go over and above in their job. They complete leadership courses and you don't see any change in their management or leadership. The employees that are the loudest and boast about what they apparently do get the recognition.  Employees feel they are on 12 month contract with no job security.  Salaries are less than what you can get elsewhere.  Lots of great people leaving and it's not acknowledged why we are losing good talent and will continue to do so.

job_title: Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The quality and qualifications of Cisco employee is extremely high and the competitive atmosphere drives innovation, collaboration and working to "go the extra mile".   Cisco also drives a culture of fairness, diversity, collaboration and results that are "second to none".  We also have the most energetic and motivational CEO in the world!
cons: The compensation is mediocre with base salaries just above the industry median and the stock is flat.  We are falling way behind the industry.   As mentioned many times, the company demands a lot out of its employees and the new culture of collaboration leads me to my day job of attending 6-8 meetings each day and my night job is reading email.  We are driving our business at break-neck speeds and I don't see the same focus and attention on the people aspect of the business as we did say 5-7 years ago.  It is a stressful environment to work in but I love my job.... sigh....  It's a company of many type A personalities.  Is the human body capable of keeping up this Cisco-pace?

review_title: Improving quality starts with the management
job_title: Software Engineer in Milpitas, CA
pros: If you want stability, good benefits, flexibility and management that is more likely to shuffle staff around than fire them, then this is the place.
cons:
There is probably no money for fair raises and promotions because you were stupid enough to join Cisco directly, rather than a start-up that got bought out,
Too much critical software is farmed out to contract engineering firms with a questionable quality track record, you may end up constantly cleaning their mess,
Products have long lifetimes so there is a lot of legacy code and "historical reasons" for poor designs,
Project management is chaotic, 
Processes are paperwork heavy but still do not result in good documentation of software and designs,

review_title: The Slow Bleed Has Become a Hemorrhage
job_title: Director in Chicago, IL
pros: There are still some talented people left, but most are actively seeking employment elsewhere
cons:
Stock options are no longer issued.

Cisco has no formal management training program--and it shows.  Sales management consists of a bunch of idiots who are just political mafia players--very short on talent, high on themselves.  They treat their people so poorly that it is beyond me how Cisco can end up on anyone's "Best Companies" list.  

Pay used to be above market rate, but is now sub par.  Engineers are poorly paid, and sales goals are now very much unattainable from year-to-year.  Cisco is managing compensation via unattainable goaling.

Annual layoffs have absolutely demoralized the company.  The rank and file sales and engineering teams now worry EVERY DAY about looking good rather than doing the right thing for the customer.  It is a sad state of affairs.

review_title: Excellent Work-Life Integration & Balance but Limited Advancement Depending on Group
job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Work remotely; make a real difference for over 70,000 employees by steadily improving internal systems. I'm lucky to work on something I love with a really fun and smart scrappy group. If not for this dynamic, would leave.
cons: Annual Big Bang and continuous rolling layoffs is difficult; despite all the layoffs, headcount has held steady between 67k and 73k for the past decade - so the company is essentially at least attempting to let go of low performing individuals and groups to hire in growth areas while keeping control on cost. Despite best efforts on this, many good people get sucked back out to sea in these politically charged restructurings. RSU funding is extremely limited for my team, only top 5% (key performers) of individual contributors get any grants. IMHO, comp generally not competitive with industry. If you join Cisco, be super aggressive on negotiating on the way in - once you're in the system, even harder to move the needle on your base comp.

review_title: Good company on the road to make itself a great.
job_title: Business Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: Great benefits, excellent work environment and peers--i never had any issues with any manager. The work flow is steady. Managers are smart. Frugal, but understand when money needs to be spent. Education their employees is important to them and they have a  pleathora of workshops to get engineers and managers up to speed. I love using their collaboration tools--they test products with their employees before sending them out customers. I think it's smart and increase our productivity. As a mobile worker, I find i spend more time working outside the office than at the office. Cisco is very flexible in how we work, and that improves how we live, play, and learn.
cons: Lower than average salary for G&A. However engineers get paid very well. Upper level management communication is lacking which is directly correlated to its vertical hierarchy. Too many lines of management. 2500 directors in the company, i wonder how many managers there are.

review_title: Once one of the best to work for, now sadly on the downhill slide towards mediocrity.
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Richardson, TX
pros: Name recognition, good reputation, was once a meritocracy where pay and advancement were actually based upon your competence and contribution. Maybe it will be again, but not now.
cons: Lack of innovation, arrogance when it comes to what customers want vs what thet R&D teams want to develop, huge growth of middle and upper management from other companies has ruined the once unique Cisco culture - making it just another big company. Continual empire-building with teams trying to rip off other teams. Lack of focus on the product. Lack of true leadership in the executive ranks at VP-Director level, especially in the Customer Advocacy/Service Provider LOB, where the execs seem more interested in 'going along to get along' rather than providing true vision or leadership. Some current cost-cutting measures have done nothing more than pass along Cisco's cost of doing business to their employees. Chambers has become very quiet and hands-off - I wonder what he thinks of what Cisco has become?

review_title: One of the best Company to work
job_title: IT Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Cisco is one of the best place to work. You would notice same company culture & standards all Cisco offices across the globe.  Cisco gives lot of important to its core values and ethics. You never notice partiality or unethical behavior in your day to day life over here. If you have offer from Cisco, there is no reason to think twice. 

Cisco pay lot of attention to employee benefits, it doesn’t need to  be always cash benefit, other benefits like health insurance, and bonus etc are best compare to industry.

Work life balance,
flexibility in work, 
Working from home, 
Technical exposure,
Great Leadership
Wonderful internal culture
Very relaxed work environment
cons:
Pay is slightly lower than market,
Promotions and pay hikes takes longer than expected
Too Process oriented 
No travel opportunity

review_title: A lot of nice talk and very little action
job_title: Human Resources Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Large company that has a well-known name and a pretty comprehensive salary package.  There are some very bright people you will have the chance to work with in your role, and the company has some good CSR programs.
cons: The company talks a lot about transparency but there is very little to none at this time.  Employees often can't tie their work to the overall goals of the company, typically because the goals are constantly in flux.  The promotion opportunities are unclear, as are the steps that you need to take to achieve one.  It is also a true matrix structure, which makes it very difficult in terms of dotted-line reporting relationships, lack of accountability, and being pulled in a lot of different directions.

job_title: Team Lead in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Excellent benefits (time off, crazy maternity/paternity leave, free college, etc), good pay, looks great on a resume. 

If you like working in TAC (support), you could do it until you retire. It's very hard to get fired.
cons:
Getting a promotion or even a raise can be very difficult in TAC. If you are an innovative person, life at Cisco can be hard because Cisco wants you to be a cog in the machine. 

Teams in TAC with difficult to support products can find themselves overwhelmed with work, while teams supporting other products have nothing to do.

There are multiple customer service offerings at Cisco who's day to day job comes down to nagging TAC about support cases regardless of case progress/status.

Cisco wants to be agile like a startup but has too much overhead in terms of sticking to the status quo and propping up legacy business units to move quickly. 

There seems to be a lot of pointless changes that happen only to justify the existence of whatever team is responsible for making the changes.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
- Excellent infrastructure (workspaces/labs/IT support/TAC) to support engineers.
- Challenging technical work.Plenty of opportunities to work
   on problems faced by largest SP's and web OTT customers 
    like AT&T/Verizon/Facebook/google/amazon etc.
- Large pool of talented and experienced software
  and hardware professionals.
- Great access to cisco's global engineering talent.
- Mgmt largely expects and values initiative and self driven attitude
   from employees.
- *Only* Top performers well taken care of in terms of overall compensation,
   equity grants/bonus etc.
- Best employee transport system in bangalore.
- Flexi time.There is opportunity to achieve work-life balance.
   Looks like someone might pull the plug on this one soon :)
cons:
-  Pay viz a viz competition needs to be reviewed.
-  Its not clear to employees whether management considers
    loyal long term employees as assets or liabilities :)

review_title: Great tech brand, very flexible, continues to evolve, legacy culture
job_title: Senior Business Development Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Best part is the flexibility if you're in a role that allows it, and most do.  Very strong brand with the enterprise helps drive the business as well as great solutions makes you a proud employee of Cisco.  People are nice and want to help, made lots of friends.  Great benefits depending on which region you're part of, but mostly ok stuff.
cons: Can be more competitive in the pay, especially for internal employees... no one internally can get equity for switching positions but a new employee can and could come in and make same/more salary wise.  Lots of politics that is not needed and legacy policies and processes could use a revamp.

review_title: Cisco has become old and confused
job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco built the internet with no protocol religion, even though IP became the defacto standard. There is a lot of diversity in the company, both technically and culturally, which made it an interesting company to be part of. The international aspect of the company and the willingness to incorporate international values also contributes to the cosmopolitan feel of the company.
cons: Parts of the business have become mature technology, and have lost their fun value. The grind of becoming the #1 vendor in many aspects of IT and Telecommunications has turned the exciting place to work, into a technology factory with little innovation and no radical thinking. Producing the numbers for the next quarter is more important than technical innovation or product development. Even the buildings in San Jose look tired and jaded now. Cisco talks about collaboration, it's the buzzword of the year, but very little collaboration exists within Cisco today, this is an empire of ivory towers.

job_title: Software Engineer II in Bangalore
pros:
1) Work life balance
2) Pays Bonus even when the market might not be great.
3) Senior management is approachable.
4) Team members are generally and genuinely very helpful.
5) if you are working on a good projects the learning is simply too good.
6) Tech-talks, trainings and tech-related events are awesome.

Apart from the above, plenty of benefits such as. [listing few of them]
1) Company pays for Broadband @ home.
2) Flexible working hours [as long as work is not getting impacted]
3) Medicare and Annual health check-ups.
4) 'Superb' Cab facility.
5) Child care facility in the campus.
6) The Bangalore Campus is simply amazing. I've seen people coming to office on weekends to relax, walk, play and have fun.
cons:
1) Off late too many organisational changes. [might be a good thing;  not according to me]
2) "Crying baby gets more milk" -- sort of a mentality. Hikes and promotions not always awarded per 'merit'.
3) Good amount of churn in the senior management suggesting things might not be that stable currently.
4) Most of the times your roadmap is not clear. Maximum visibility is I guess for coming 3 months.
5) Sometimes it is just fire fighting for weeks and months. Whatever comes up has 'ASAP' tagged to it.

job_title: Senior Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Cisco is literally the company that made the internet - so it has some smart people and a huge customer & partner base. Work culture varies from group to group so it is hard to characterize it any one way.
cons: The culture for Cisco has changed significantly from the 90s when it was a technology company singularly looking to get more market share with a variety of different technologies. Now the culture is primarily focused on politics. This feedback is primarily focused at Services and the culture there. A lot of the management is not barely familiar with the technology. When they get barely familiar with the technology, they are playing catch with where the market direction may be headed. Then there is complete ignorance of where the industry is heading with technologies such Virtualization, Analytics and Services in general. Management rewards each other with pats on the back and results of Services performance is not reviewed and weighed as a metric for evaluation. WIth the result innovation is stiffled.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Atlanta, GA
pros: Solid benefits, good pay.  You'll meet a lot of good people.
cons: Management is weak.  Promotion from within is very much based on social connections not necessarily earned in every case.  Those promoted are not trained in managing people nor are they educated on company policy and process so when direct reports go to them for help it is seldom given.  The annual layoffs are unfortunately required as the company is poorly equipped to manage the bottom 10% out of the company, again, due to poorly trained managers and a weak performance management process.  I left on my own for a promotion but more importantly to feel valued, challenged and to get away from a really arrogant and incompetent management structure. I could have stayed and had the easiest pay check in the world but I respect my capabilities more than being a guy that fits the suit.

review_title: Early in Career, not Entry Level
job_title: Financial Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: I joined Cisco straight from college in 2017, specifically the LIFT (finance rotation) program. This 2-year (four six-month rotations) program is a great introduction to the many functions within a global finance organization. I've felt empowered to explore the company with my own interests and passions in mind. Everyone holds the program in high regards, and it has been a great way to get leadership experience. Cisco's Early Career Network also invests in creating an environment of exploration and networking that fosters creativity and innovation within the many employees who are 1-5 years into their career at Cisco. Through this organization, I have had the privilege to connect with similarly motivated people all over the world!
cons: Any global company comes with its bureaucratic challenges, but Cisco maintains a culture of curiosity and innovation that encourages growth throughout your career through challenging the status quo. Change takes time, but it starts here.

review_title: Changing the way we live, work and play....but with less excitement and passion
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Breath of products, lots to learn about how technology solutions can be implemented.  Chamber is a very charismatic leader that always looks at possibilities; he as definitely a glass half-full exec. Also because there are many different functions, there are more opportunities to try different roles.  Health and medical benefits are still quite good(unfortunately employees are asked to shoulder more of the financial burden). The new health center and child care center is STATE of the ART.
cons: Even though we have a great CEO, that charisma does not flow down to most of the executive team. It is a BIG & bureaucratic company now.  I was here during the late 1990s boom and a LOT has changed.  There's a lot of mid-managers that just suck the life out of you because they don't care about leading, rather they care about managing their own next promotion. Lots of "fringe" benefits that were part of Cisco are slowly being taken away (i.e., free sodas, company paid broadband, etc).  Those were nice while they lasted.

review_title: A perfect place to work - if you are average or slightly above an average engineer
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Lawrenceville, GA
pros:
Work environment is beautiful and well equipped.
Flexibility 
Stability
High Technology
cons:
Management simply treats most engineers as replaceable.

Horrible management of software code base  with respect to customer releases results in poor usage of SW Engineers.  Most are getting burned out doing upkeep work and all new work seems to go to contractors.  

Management makes it known that engineers cannot be involved in business and completely shields them from any of it.

review_title: Was  a Great Place to Work
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Reno, NV
pros: I worked for Cisco for 20 years, 11 months and enjoyed most everyday. I had a lot of opportunity to grow my talents and participate in making the internet what it is today. Worked many hours and traveled a lot but it was well worth it. Met a lot of great people all over the world.
cons: After 20+ years I was all of sudden laid off along with 800 other employees. I was not given any opportunity to find another position or any reason why I was being let go. I was planning to retire in 4 years and now due to my age I am having a hard time finding a new job. Since the new CEO took over the company has gone downhill as far as loyalty to employees is concerned. Most people I know are always worried about being laid off. I would not recommend Cisco to anyone now as long as this culture persist.

job_title: SE-III in Bangalore
pros:
- Just brand name, legacy reputation, and big market capture in Networking domain. 
- It's a group of many small startups, say. So, if you fall in good BU, you will get good work, exposure, hikes, and live in peace.
- Nice clean big campus, facilities, gym, office infra.
- Pays huge to freshers from premium colleges, and to Senior Management.
cons:
- Pays Low Salary as per market standard of Product companies. Lesser than some big service companies.  Always postpone yearly hike cycles by 1 or 2 quarters.
- Regular firing/LR.
- Too much work pressure. Too many product lines make it difficult to learn for Engineers. Customer escalations, bug counts are day to day worries. Very few old employees left who know product details, so no one is there to help.  
- Managers & Sr. Managers insulate engineers from Directors & VP who are real decision makers for hike & promotions. So mid-level engineers suffer from both side (lot of difficult work, and minimal hikes). Managers take credit & themselves get promoted.
- More suffering for people in Infra, platform, services, etc.

job_title: Talent Acquisition Manager in Miami, FL
pros: Cisco has a great culture - we encourage our employees to be active in their communities and to volunteer, we have a strong team environment, and we are encouraged to innovate and take risks.  We have great collaboration tools that allow many employees to work remotely and we do encourage work/life balance.  I love my team,  my peers and the future of Cisco as a leader in technology.
cons: Learning to navigate your way around Cisco can be a challenge.  It is a very big and complex organization, but your teammates will help you! There are pockets of bureaucracy and legacy behaviors that we could improve on.  We need to integrate some of our tools and become more cutting edge.

review_title: Great Company, hard at times to stand out.
job_title: TAC Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Cisco has many pros for working there which is due to the size of the company, they can offer great benefits
- Willing to hire new grads and give great new grad pay
- Great benefits, time off, time to give (40 hours), and baby leave
- They equip you with all the equipment you need to be successful
- Leadership is very open
- Laid off due to restructuring right before COVID-19 (Feb 25th) but they provided a tremendous package.
- Work/Life balance is great if you set boundaries.
cons:
- The pay starts great as a new grad but is quickly average competitive compared to jobs area the area.
- Since the company is so large every position or opportunity you will see quite a bit of competition
-Quite a lot of change happening within orgs. Large company, so this is to be expected. However, about every year you will experience layoffs in some departments, new managers, etc.
- If you don't know how to network, learn it. That's the only way you can stand out in a company this large.

review_title: Cisco has become another large company and suffers from "large company-itis".
job_title: Director in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco is a stable, very large company. Has a very good sales & channel organization; decent benefits. Talented resources if engaged properly.
cons: Large company with too much political baggage. Employees & organizations that are not based in San Jose suffer from a compensation perspective, respect and career growth. The overall compensation of the company has suffered over the past 8-10 years as well. It appears to me that Cisco does not value it's experienced employees; hires too much from the outside in key positions without allowing experienced employees a shot at the promotional opportunity. "You're better off to quit, gain a more impressive title from a smaller company and then reapply to Cisco". Your chances of getting promoted are better using that tactic then trying to justify it internally.

review_title: Great Experience Until I got Laid off (as a Consultant) due to Budget Cuts
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible work hours (opportunity to work from home if your manager allows it).  I found Cisco to be an intellectually stimulating work environment since most of my colleagues were very intelligent, hard-working, and collaborative.  There are some very interesting projects and many opportunities to learn new skills.  I had a great manager that offered opportunities to work on increasingly challenging projects if they were available and a person was performing successfully.
cons: Senior management does not really understand what kind of resources are needed to implement some of these projects.  Some of the funding and staffing decisions that have been made have been disastrous to the successful outcome of projects, which can be measured by the quality of the implementation and number and severity of issues after Go-Live.  They do not understand that going live does not necessarily mean going live successfully.

review_title: The good times are more of a memory now
job_title: Systems Engineer III in Feltham, England
pros: Great brand name and strong foundation on what used to be a great company. Lots of flexibility if you have the right manager and can persuade them what you're doing is right. The opportunity to work with some very bright people (harder to find these days) and with leading edge technology. Open corporate culture.
cons:
More redundancies creating a culture of fear and resentment. Job and career uncertainty by continual hiring freezes and arbitrary changes in expense policy. Sustained effective pay cuts such as reduction in restricted stock, no more company-provided internet, no more soft beverages, unreasonable goals (taxes) for technical people not based on merit. Reduction in hiring quality and talent recognition.

No one will tell you these are the glory days. They're long gone. This is a company that pretends to itself it's still cool and fun. But it really, really isn't.

review_title: I enjoyed the people I worked with
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Great people in some areas of the company. Good pay and benefits. Worked from home for over five years made for a great work-life balance. If you find the right group the work can be very satisfying.
cons:
Too many people that don't contribute to the value of the company should be let go but the process for firing people takes 6+ months. Therefore, there are many people that are just moved around to avoid the firing process. Managers are "highly" encouraged to move people rather than fire them. Cisco seems to side with the bad employee for fear of reprisal and litigation.
Too many people caught up in following the "shiny ball" and not doing the right thing for the customer.
Little innovation from within the company. Difficult to get promoted unless you have a technology background.
Cutting free soda seemed like a good idea from a cost standpoint but had a greater negative impact on moral. It's the little things.

review_title: A great career with a good company that has changed over the years
job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The opportunity to move around within the company in different roles is something that you don't find at many companies, however that comes with a con (see cons below). The pay and benefits are pretty competitive as I'm finding out and the flexibility to manage work/life is key but you pay for that in other ways (see cons below).
cons: Constant org changes usually lead to opportunities but they also lead to confusion and politics. Your boss and organization can change 4-5 times over as many years but your role stays the same. The global nature of how Cisco is structured makes it an interesting place to work but depending on your role you can be working 24x6 as you have to satisfy Europe, Asia and US timezones which necessitates you to work through the evening every night just to catch up.

review_title: Great Company, Motivated Employees,  Excellent work environment
job_title: Senior Manager, Strategy and Operations in San Jose, CA
pros:
Good people- majority of my managers and employees have been smart and self motivated.  People care about their jobs, care about their co-workers, care about the community.

Love the moto:  "Best in the world, Best for the world".    Relentless focus on execution, without losing need to do good in the world.  

Great work-life balance.  Employees work hard, but flex time is the norm.  Very common to have 7am calls, 7pm calls, but also ok to be coaching soccer at 4pm, or at doctor's appt with your mother in the middle of the day
cons:
Many people have been here a long time- there's a sense of entitlement amongst those here 20+ years.  Some complacency, related to above.

Hard to move up- promotions to director level and above seems to require inside connections.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Austin, TX
pros: Cisco is a great company to work for in the sales force if you are seeking autonomy and are a self starter.  The more responsibility you seek, the more you will get.  They are also big on using their own technology to collaborate and complete your daily work.  They are also big on information exchange and internal education - there is usually more technical content that one can absorb.  Overall, I think Cisco sales is a good place to work!
cons: over the period of time I have been with Cisco, I have seen the layers of management grow and the result has made for a lengthy process to get things accomplished.  The continued thickening of processes and procedures is certainly slowing everything down.  One can spend more time on internal meetings than doing what we were employed to do - sell.  Cisco is also no longer the best in compensation, it hands out fewer and fewer RSUs and the raises are in the single low digits.  As you get closer to the top of the SE pyramid, opportunities for promotions are far and few between.

job_title: Program Management Manager in Irvine, CA
pros: Cisco pays pretty well and offers good flexibility and some perks, and some of the administrative things work surprisingly well for such a giant corporation.  Cisco does a lot of good work in the community and encourages staff to give back to various charities, etc. and does a good job of promoting mobility across job functions, etc.
cons: There is a constant threat of a "Limited Restructuring" - nearly every year, you will lose some colleagues if not your own job, which absolutely kills morale.  They make a lot of noise about how great their culture is - which if you have to say it so often, means it is likely not the case.  They can be completely tone-deaf, for example, scheduling all-hands, AMA-type town-hall meetings with execs on the same days they're laying off hundreds of people, making "The People Deal" complete BS.

review_title: You're on your own (that's good and bad)
job_title: Technical Lead in San Jose, CA
pros: You're given the tools you need to do your job and you're entrusted to "do the right thing" (that was in the orientation).  There's a complete absence of micromanagement -- no one will tell you what to do, though they will sometimes provide guidance if asked, or as part of regular team operations.  Work/life balance is great; everyone is given a CVO to support working from home, which can be expected when you're working with teams all around the world.
cons: Everyone is doing their own thing.  Sometimes the pieces come together to make a functioning product/service, but only at the lowest levels.  The higher you go, the less likely it is that what you're working on will play nicely with what someone else is working on, and there is little broad leadership to tie all of the pieces together.

job_title: Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
I worked at Cisco in RTP for a few years. Over time it become obvious that my project peers were working other full-time jobs and shouldering me with an unfair amount of project burden. I made management aware of this issue but they were too busy to effectively look into the matter. It was a complicated issue; management typically doesn't have time to manage staff at Cisco and actually see whats going on. Many managers have too many employees, some like mine have the title of manager but are really too busy working a sales role. This puts them in the place of trusting mid-level employees.If your under a shady one theres not much you can do.
It got very shady in my exit interview when no HR representative was present. In lieu of that I was given a web form to fill out.

Pros: Great opportunities do exist. as with most large companies Its really a roll of the dice as to who you work for.
cons: As stated the cliques and poor ethics that grow in certain areas.

review_title: Some good, some bad, mostly confusing
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Many of the people I worked with were friendly and helpful
You were given the resources needed to do your job -- a decent laptop, phone, etc.
Lots of career mobility if you are a full time employee 
Training opportunities were available, even for contractors (!)
Nice campus with decent amenities for a company of its size (gym, cafeteria, etc.)
cons:
More meetings than you can possibly imagine
Inconsistency between departments on how employees/contractors were treated 
Contractors are not given feedback on their performance until too late 
"Cisco Rule" applied randomly inside company -- some groups kept everyone year after year while others laid off their entire staff for almost no reason
Poor employees often manage to squeak through the cracks while good ones get terminated
Simple projects often become unnecessarily complex because of the need for consensus by EVERYONE.
Extremely big company -- very easy to sit in an environment and not know who your neighbors are or what they do for years unless you introduce yourself to them

review_title: Technically-limited staff desperately trying to appear relevant by using acronyms
job_title: Systems Engineer in Amsterdam
