pros: Still a decent name to have on your profile, pay is still ok, but dropping fast. Plenty of internal training resources and focus on being a good workplace
cons:
Though they'll claim otherwise, the culture is all about the sale, leaving the technology on the back burner. Of course the majority of the sales staff have limited tech capability anyway, so they wouldn't know the difference. But in spite of all the talk of innovation and disruption, it's just that - talk. The product suite is ageing and there's little on the horizon to address that. Much talk about programmability, yet a huge percentage of the company doesn't have the most basic of coding skill, which shows painfully in the work product.

Salaries are diving, advancement is hindered by significant headcount pressure in many regions. Country director up seems to see the market for what it is, but most people below that are hiding their heads in the sand or at war with some other business unit. Lots of talk about transparency and open feedback, but nobody is actually interested in hearing anything that doesn't confirm their existing view.

review_title: Good, but Could Be Much Better
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
• Work-life balance is prime here and everyone respects people’s personal time
• Culture is fairly nice and open. Not cutthroat
• Great for anyone looking for a stable, predictable job — especially good for people taking care of a family (onsite daycare, maternity + paternity leave, etc)
cons:
• Salary negotiation is non-existent if you are hired through the university program. Really. Nor is team matching.
• Promotions are rare and are often based on inter-company politics. When they are awarded, they are underwhelming and don’t match the local rent inflation
• RSUs are very rare and, again, very political / based on team+BU
• There is always talk about innovation by the leadership, but the culture is fairly stale as are the products, so opportunities for innovation are few and far between
• No free food or snacks. A couple of buildings do have free snacks, but it was for a “beta snacks program” that was never spread company wide.

review_title: good to start, but definitely have to leave
job_title: Lead Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
worked here for 4 years and quit to progress my career:
1. Work life balance is great. 
2. A lot of the people are really fun and there's definitely a lot of help if you need it. 
3. Really open to learning and continuing your learning
cons:
oh man after 4 years you definitely start seeing the cracks:
1. Open discrimination against men is pretty tolerant here, I.E. opportunities and events only women can attend and sign up here.
2. You're underpaid from day 1,  don't expect that to change, the next year's new grads will come in at a higher pay than you.
3. Career progression doesn't happen too often, you'll definitely get the work but never the monetary or career recognition.
4. Some pretty toxic LGBTQ+ people I.E.  I was told it was "good that I was discriminated against because I'm not a minority."

job_title: Web Developer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Telecommuting is encouraged
Teams are competent and unified
Internal transfers are easy
Code ownership is shared to relieve pressure against vacations
Training and higher education is supported
cons:
Micromanagement is rampant and backed up by a culture of fear

External tools are poorly chosen, overvalued as silver bullets, and not optimized to fit the needs of developers

Employee evaluation system is based on an individual's reputation for working long hours, oratory skills in meetings, powerpoint skills in presentations, and popularity with upper management

Advice of developers is disregarded by technical leads and managers, yet failure is always attributed to a lack of effort and communication among the team

Project marketing and team size are used as leverage among management, leading to unhealthy competition between teams, code redundancy, and useless features creeping into requirement lists

Hard work is not rewarded as much as shameless self promotion and socializing outside the office

Deadlines and milestones are decided without any input from developers implementing the requests

job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Good company name on your resume, recruiters will try to snatch you up if you start looking for another job outside the company.
Engineers know their stuff well
Lots of perks (CAP awards for a project well done, good onsite cafeteria, gym, etc)
Company has many business units covering many technology areas
cons:
sweat shop: expect 70+ hours of work regularly if you are an engineer.
high pressure: not only do you have to put in long hour, it is a high pressure environment. Every one is pressuring everyone else to get the work done, leading to a very nasty environment and teamwork suffers a lot. People just do not have time to help others unless it is something that is "visible" by their management.
Company frugality policy means you do not have the resources (equipment) to actually do the work expected of you. People spend a lot of wasted time fighting over equipment and making do with prototype that do not work.

review_title: Great company and people but limited opportunities for promotion
job_title: in Feltham, England
pros:
- Working environment is excellent - facilities are modern, always being updated, refreshed
- Use of technology - webex, telepresence, unified comms makes it easy to work with virtual teams
- Good opportunities and challenges - able to make a difference
- Can over achieve on your bonus if company overachieves
- Stock awarded for good performance
cons:
- Progression in terms of pay and promotions is far too slow - lots of people waiting to get to the next level, management don't deliver on commitments, unclear and inconsistent promotion process
- Reward & recognition is inconsistent - some rewarded for doing little, others nothing for doing a lot
- Too much complexity - strategy, systems etc - undergoing major simplification effort now but a little too late
- Pay rises only when the company has made it's numbers (even through inflation has gone up and the company has huge cash reserves)

review_title: Varies immensely depending on your manager
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Looks great on a resume; employers love to hire ex-Cisco employees
- Great benefits
- Many co-workers are smart; some are very smart indeed!
- Much of the employee education is top-notch
- Flexible work hours and work-remote policies
cons:
- A bad manager can really make things terrible, and there isn't really anything you can do about it; bad managers tend to stay in place indefinitely, unless they quit
- Salary is generally below-par
- Stock price has been flat, so options and ESPP aren't worth much
- Major changes in direction come as a surprise to rank-and-file employees.  Your business unit could be shut down at any time, and you could wind up moving somewhere completely unrelated
- A very large organization generally means lots of process and lots of red tape
- Cisco has apparently started doing annual layoffs, dumping 10%-20% of their employees each time.  Morale problems are endemic in part as a result of this

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bangalore
pros:
Excellent Bonus, Good work life balance, flexible timing, work-from-home, No desktops at all, everyone gets laptop.
Great resting place between two demanding jobs, may be for an year or two
People including Managers are very good, treatment of employees is very good
Cafeteria facilities are very good, at least in Cessna Business Park which houses Cisco's own campus.
Transport facility is there at a reasonable price for permanent employees, contractors can avail of it but pretty expensive for them.
Easy hiring for contractors, the process is tougher for permanent employees
cons:
Not a great place if you are career-oriented.
Things move too slowly, and hardly anything ever gets done
Vision and Strategy is missing for most BUs. No long-term thinking.
Stay longer, and employability outside decreases phenomenally
Ad-hoc, difficult-to-explain firings (not necessarily bad performers)
Promotions are very difficult. 
Un-organized hierarchy, nobody know which designation is senior or junior, or who falls where.
No HR involvement once you get hired, they only recruit you after that they never check on you. 
Contractors to Permanent Employees ratio is approx 8:2 (this could be BU specific), and hiring of contractual workers is very lenient, so you end up with lots of poor performers.

review_title: A once-wonderful company has lost their vision and their employees are now paying for it
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: If you're willing to work around the clock (I have a 1AM-6AM meeting tomorrow, and another on Sunday) you can do very well at Cisco.
cons: Cisco has gone to a "management by council" mode so nobody seems to have accountability anymore.  Chambers and team seem to be floundering, badly, after making some really bad decisions that they now have to rectify.  Rumor has it huge layoffs are coming soon, and budgets are being slashed in really scary places.

review_title: Cisco is still the 800 lb Gorilla but lost some appeal to work for
job_title: Software Development Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Portfolio of products/services and sales force are a juggernaut
- Incredibly strong financial position
- Competitive total compensation
cons:
- Lack of vision and 'old school' leadership
- Higher priority on balance sheet than it's people and developing a compelling vision
- Direction is to grow in China, India, etc. and Outsourcing. Quality of some products and services are noticeably lower.
- Lost it's appeal and growth potential due to above

review_title: Good ole boys manage the company for the most part leaving playground bullies and back stabbing thugs the winners.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Competitive Salary and bonus plan although bonuses are rarely paid unless you can walk on water.
cons: Uses Bell Curve to force those rated as lowest are placed on probation or terminated, those in the mid 74% range get patted on the head and told try harder next time, and only those in the top percentile get raises, perks, bonuses, and or promotions. Sounds like a great incentive plan until you realize that out of 100 people every year roughly 14% have to be put on probation and a percentage of those have to be terminated. My former manager is a bigot and sexist so he used his power to drive people out he didn't approve of and with a PC approach to justify his racism and sexist views. Hopefully HR has outed him for what he is and he isn't bullying people anymore. But Crisco promotes these values from my experience and rallys around such people at management levels so work as hard as you may your number will eventually be up, unless you're the Sociopath that can manipulate the system in your favor.

job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Cicso has a good benefits package and they have $$ in the bank.  I think of them as IBM of the 1990's -- No one was ever fired for buying Cisco.  You start with 20 days of PTO a year.
cons:
IMHO, Routers/switches have become commodity  products.  Years ago, cisco had a sufficient technology lead that they could charge premium.  Today, they are marginally better, if that.

Not an easy place to work.  Engineers were given responsibility without Resources/empowerment.  Big company politics in place.  It felt that you are on call 24x7.  Significant development efforts in India Yearly focal reviews put you in competition with your peers, resulting in subtle anti-colaboration.  There is not a lot in innovation coming from the company.  Cisco Buys new technology. 

Development is process burdened.  

There is little respect for Seasoned professionals, company has been pushing to get young talent and push out
experienced engineers.  Seems to me that this is a "bean counter" approach with the assumption that all bodies are equal.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco campuses have many amenities. There are many ways that you can stand out. They have a large infrastructure which can be supportive. Teams are open and friendly to new people and it is easy to make friends if you come with an open attitude.
cons: Cisco is an enterprise! There are so many departments within Cisco that no one knows or often dares to ask what they do. Often part of your job might be researching what departments and who are is in charge of the elements you have the responsibility of improving or changing. In some departments they are just now embracing Agile development. Alas to do so they are using multiples of online tools that don't interact with each other. It seems most departments prefer using spreadsheets that are not live or shared and have to be updated by every member of the team to 'stay up-to-date'.

review_title: Job security is scary at times
job_title: Technical Support Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Excellent benefits and starting pay is competitive.
cons: Raises are almost non-existent.  Raises do occur, but they seem to be only for a small section of employees at the absolute top of the performance scale or who have made the right impression with senior leadership.  So you can do a great job and not see a penny more for 3 or more years.  So while the world becomes more expensive to live in, you are are having less an less expendable income.  If this methodology resulted in more job security it would be worth it, but it is just Cisco's normal business model to force management into stack ranking exercises to determine who could be fired.  Also, Cisco does not value most experience gained outside of Cisco.  So you may have years of experience coming in the door, you will not be considered for promotions until you have gained the same experience under Cisco.

review_title: Live, Love, Lead at Cisco and Be The Bridge to Possible!
job_title: Director in San Jose, CA
pros:
Cisco is not only the greatest place to work at, but in fact, it is the greatest place to live your life - by learning, innovating, creating, sharing, leading and building an impactful and successful life - personally & professionally, for yourself and for others around you. 

I have been at Cisco 12 yrs+ now and worked in 2 different continents and 5 different teams and I am as enthused , excited and grateful for each day at work (if not more), as I was when I started. 

As a woman, as a professional, as a human - I have felt supported, encouraged, valued and challenged to be the best version of myself - through the experience, exposure and education opportunities I have been equipped, enabled and empowered with.

All I am and all I hope to be ...I owe to Cisco and the people I work, live, learn, play, innovate and give back with.
cons: We are making big strides in promoting women to leadership roles across all ranks and there is more to be done with great initiatives like Multiplier Effect and Multiply Tech Diversity initiatives.

job_title: HPC Engineer in London, England
pros: Free drinks, free pizza, nice colleagues
cons: Too much pressure, fast paced business

review_title: Mixed - Good exposure, but lack of career growth opportunity
job_title: Marketing Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Lots of really smart people with good salaries and benefits. Cisco is still light years ahead of a lot of companies and that allows you to be able to move to other companies fairly easily after you've workes at Cisco. Also, being able to move around within the company used be a lot easier to do, but the last few years has been really locked down.
cons: Marketing (Operations specifically)- Management is terrible and one director in particular is completely unprofessional and has burned out a number of high quality employees. The result is a huge turn over rate in Operations and in Marketing as well. The senior management seems to allow it to continue. The result is a very negative environment with no career growth.

review_title: innovative but paranoid and not very loyal
job_title: Senior SQA Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: This is a big company with a lot of great employees and a lot of innovation.  Cisco does not want to join the long list of previously great Silicon Valley companies that missed a market transition.  They are constantly trying new strategies (which gets a little exhausting at times, throwing stuff at the wall and seeing what sticks).  I think the salary, bonus, and RSUs for top performers are very strong.
cons: 2005-2014 I thought Cisco was a great place to work, but not a good stock to own.  Now it is kind of the opposite.  If your Business Unit is not growing by 10% annually, you will get your budget cut proportionally and that money will go to the growing BUs.  Our BU growth slowed, and we got cut a little in 2014, a LOT in 2016, and now again in 2017 including me.

review_title: Cisco IT as an Early in Career employee
job_title: IT Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
The work /life balance is fantastic. I'm able to work from home whenever I'd like, and since Cisco is a global company, I've been able to travel on my own and work out of other Cisco offices without taking time off.    

5 days of paid time off to volunteer. 

The people! Everyone I've worked with has been very nice and eager to share knowlege.  

On campus gym and doctors office at a very reasonable price. 

Dogs can come in the office on Wednesdays and Fridays.
cons:
There's no IT training program for recent grads like there is for sales and HR. 

Initial team placement after recruitment was off, but I was able to rotate into an area that I'm really excited about after about a year. 

Continuous layoffs really impact office morale.

job_title: Regional Business Development Manager in Kraków

review_title: great company, but local senior management is stuck in old Scientific Atlanta methodologies
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Lawrenceville, GA
pros:
Great benefits
Good people
Have all the tools I need
Excellent review process
Great bonus system
There are ample opportunities to grow, and management within the CHS business unit at least listen to you
cons:
HR when we were Scientific Atlanta was very good.  HR at Cisco is not as responsive.
IT support has just been decimated with the latest restructuring (Aug 2011).  It's all done now by telephone support from a remote location.
SPVTG does not yet have a clear path.  However, senior management of the group has recently been changed, and these problems may be corrected. Change was indeed needed.

review_title: Great experience in switch software development but management's involvement in personal development/reward is lacking.
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, CA
pros: Very flexible work environment: working from home is easy as is taking time off. Initial on-the-job learning is good and the networking software development experience gained was valuable. Enjoy working with helpful colleagues.
cons: Compensation growth is mediocre and I do not see people getting adequate reward for performance from management. It may be the nature of the game but there is no cohesiveness in the execution of goals and deliverables. There is always a last minute scramble to push products out, and there are too many branches and people touching the same code for clean code development. No encouragement for training and personal development from management, you have to push it on your own.

review_title: One of the best companies to work for, especially when you have seen others
job_title: Technical Leader in Hamburg
pros: You are able to work with some of the best and smartest folks in the industry. Compensation is good and and opportunities to advance are available, even though competition is tough. The company knows how to align employee behavior with the goals of the company.
cons: It is a "Hero-to-Zero" company. Come end of July the latest, expect major shifts in focus areas, responsibilities, expectations. In sales, do expect your targets to go up in a way that makes you ask "How possibly can I achieve that ?". Feature velocity in products sometimes low as there are sometimes too many diverging interests.

review_title: Great place to work if you manage your career and network
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: There's a lot of opportunities at this enormous global company with fantastic benefits - but no one is going to hand hold you to develop your career. It's really easy to get paid well, work 9-5 and be at Cisco for a decade, if you want a mommy-track or low key job. If you want to learn, be challenged, move up fast, learn the org landscape, find the right sponsors and there are lots of interesting learning experiences to be had.
cons: Political, big and slow in many parts of the org. Back channel negotiation and side discussions are required to smoothly get stuff done, and not doing so has career ramifications. That said, if you understand the landscape, you can do well. Had great experiences and career development, but ultimately I left because I wanted more direct impact than what I could see as a cog in the massive machine that is Cisco. That said, it was worth the tour of duty

job_title: in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco Systems at RTP by far has been one of the best experiences.  The University Experience team and made the process seamless. As an intern, onboarding week made me feel comfortable and welcomed with open arms. The opportunities at Cisco Systems are endless. With the love and support of my colleagues, I was given the opportunity to learn about myself, team work and why Cisco Systems is the #1 Technology company in the world. My projects were challenging and one-one-one sessions with key stakeholders in the company were engaging as well. I was given the opportunity to solve one of Cisco's problems and present my findings to management, and the VP of my org. Definitely my best internship by far and would recommend the company to others. I have chosen to stay at Cisco for my first post-college career position.
cons: Not so much of a bad thing, but Cisco is what you make it! It is completely up to you on how your career will be at the company.  I have learned this very quickly in my internship and will be keep it with me as I begin full-time.

job_title: Technical Marketing Leader in San Jose, CA
pros: Great company. Great work culture. Highly talented people. The company provides opportunities for growth, career transitions, mentoring. I mean it's up to the employee to make the best use of the opportunities available. I got my immigration work also done by Cisco. Even after I left Cisco, I got support from Fragomen. I must say I am very very impressed by the way Cisco takes care of their employees and former employees.
cons: I don't like the new open workspace concept. It's very chaotic and highly unproductive. Most of the employees at Cisco don't like it. I didn't meet anyone who liked it. But still, it was enforced. It was disappointing to see Cisco didn't care about employees opinion. I can understand that it's highly cost-effective to stuff double the employees in the same old space.

job_title: HW Engineer in Bangalore
pros: You will be working mostly in cutting edge technology. Very rarerly people has to work on older technology. You will get to know the complete networking domain expertise exposure. Limitless learning opportunities - on demand video lectures, soft skill development opportunities - unlike other companies in Cisco this is not restricted. It is upto you to utilise. Other companies it depends on managers. Top level management is very good and the open culture and the work environment is awesome.
cons: You have to manage and uplift your self - both time management, career, work life balance etc. No body cares. Managers care only your work completion. Too many emails - you like or not daily must to waste 2 to 4 hours time in emails. If your manager is not good then you will be in trouble to complete your task in time.

job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Opportunity to work on great technology. In addition, the executive management is the best I've seen in working for various companies in Silicon Valley. Flexible work hours (though you need to work extremely hard). Varied set of products, so if you get bored doing something, you can move to something completely different without changing jobs.
cons:
Pay is not great: especially if you've been around for some time. Newcomers get paid market rates, while old-timers struggle to get raises.
Raises are hard to come by, and are highly dependent on your manager and group. 

Middle management sucks. The executives are excellent, and their strategic vision has kept Cisco going, however, there's an enormous amount of deadwood,  that needs cleaning. Too many directors sit around doing nothing and don;t get fired, in some ways its like getting tenure at Cisco to become a director.
A lot of engineering will probably end up being moved to India, so watch out. 
Has gotten fairly bureaucratic, so getting things done is hard.

job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: If you like working countless hours on things that often are more political vs. meaningful, then this is the place for you.  If your career is your life, then this is the place to dive in and see where it takes you.
cons: Too much CYA required.  Management sees what it wants to see and often recognizes ones who are better political contributors rather than true work contributors. Work-life balance doesn't exist if you want to survive.  The political side of Cisco came to the surface during/after the 2001 layoff.  It has thrived since.  Finally training of new managers has only just begun.  Promoting someone from within to management (who has never been a manager before) is a gamble. Training is not adequate.  Thus many employees suffer.

job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, CA
pros: As an engineer I think some of the best reasons to work for Cisco is the opportunity to work on a wide variety of technologies.  In my business unit (GSBU), people do have the freedom to work on technologies that they find interesting.  Also, the stability of working for the industry leader is nice.  In some ways, the benefits are better than any other company I have worked at (4 weeks of vacation).
cons: Recognition and promotions are difficult to come by.  It seems as if promotions have more to do with "ass kissing" than merit or accomplishments.  Also, it's not likely that you're going to make rapid career advancements.  This is a big company with a pecking order in place.  If climbing the career ladder quicker is your priority, Cisco (or any large company for that matter) is not your place.

review_title: Great internship experience, but got screwed over with the choice program.
job_title: Hardware Test Engineer
pros: Great benefits, resources, and the network. One of the best place to intern or do a 6-month co-op as an engineer.
cons:
Large corporation. Easy to get lost in the crowd of people with similar skills. Bad communication amongst different department and business units.

I was hired as a Hardware Engineer intern for the "Cisco Choice Program." The uniqueness of the program is that if you do well during your internship you will get hired back and get to interview the managers of different business units within Cisco and pick which Business Unit you want to work for.

Due to the bad economy and higher ups decisions, they decided to cut all hardware engineers position for the Cisco choice program leaving only Software and MBA students.

review_title: It's not a great place to work!
job_title: Systems Engineer III in Frankfurt am Main
pros: Finally they have some good products and it's nice to work for a leader. You have the ability to learn new technology's, to be part of the a world wide virtual team. You have the ability to learn new stuff, to work in a motivated team and to be part of this culture.
cons: There is NO work-life balance! Of course, they saying that you take your private time, but they give you workload up to 60-70  hours per week. Where is there the work-life balance or at least the possibility? The management is just thinking from quarter to quarter. Just number are important, nothing else. Ethic exist just at the paper. For the salary there is downwards trend. Meanwhile there are trying to remove all the benefits. They are just selling the future, a lot of the products are not ready or poor. Meanwhile the company is to large for fast moves. Overall: I can't recommend this company if the family is important for you.

review_title: Cisco has become a depressing place to work
job_title: Business Operations Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Salaries and benefits are generous
cons: The working environment is bad, and everyone is under pressure to do more with less. Promotions are non-existent, people don't care anymore, everyone is looking to leave to find a place with a brighter future.  Cisco is so big that the highest levels of management doesn't have any idea what the worker bees are actually doing.  The people that are laid off don't make sense.  The company is completely fragmented with VPs creating their own fiefdoms.  Cisco used to be a fun and interesting place to work at, now everyone is too busy looking over their shoulders and taking credit for work they didn't do.

review_title: Great company but not without issues
job_title: QA Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Laid back, positive environment, decent salary, good manager, forgiving environment. Some times there are inevitable frustration and hard times but it quickly vents away. Great technologies to learn. 
Free ev charger.
Some of the cafeteria are decent.
Employees can go to any of the numerous building covering massive area any time (except lab) and sit anywhere and attend meeting or do whatever.
cons:
Public newspaper says Cisco is getting fatter in the middle and need to get rid off excess mid level management. In some way, it might be true but also I saw talented and experienced engineers impacted and incompetent engineers have stayed. They really need to be careful in this respect because many many good employees have left during last year. More jobs are getting done by fewer employees as a result and quality suffers too. 

Encourages new ideas but quality/experiences takes a back seat. Quite a lot of times, there are turmoil

I feel like it is impossible to move within the company. Few other job inquiries resulted in no-reply.

review_title: Still a leader, but needs to seriously shake up its current executives
job_title: Senior Manager Business Development in San Jose, CA
pros:
- A great opprtunity to work with some serioulsy talented people, especially out in the regions
 - Benefits and salary are above the industry norm
 - Ability to expand your experience through different roles within the company, out in the regions and at HQ
cons:
- You have to wonder how some people especially at corporate are still  in their roles.. they should have gone a long while ago,  while some of the hard working, talented individuals have either moved on, or will soon do so, due to high frustration levels.
 - Still an old boys club mentality at the top...
 - Many executives have been there too long... need to bring in some fresh blood and a new way of thinking.
 - Recently lost its way with too much restructuring... it is breeding discontentment and bad morale in a big way.

review_title: Potential is tremendous, but held back by ossified management and divisional politics
job_title: Business Development Manager in Boxborough, MA
pros: There are a tremendous number of very talented and motivated individuals at Cisco with great experience and expertise across the networking technology space, but poor senior management who exhibit flawed strategic planning and execution skills, weakened by self-interest and self-promotion of these executives, leads to sub-par outcomes in a variety of product and market spaces.
cons: Senior management needs major change - including John Chambers - to reinvigorate the company and to help drive winds of change within engineering and product line teams.  A top-heavy management structure needs to be flattened and thinned, and allow for movement of talented and strong performers from lower organizational levels to rise to address new challenges.

review_title: The Bean Counters Have Taken Over
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Richardson, TX
pros: Competitive Salary, Annual Bonus, great IT department.
cons:
I worked at Cisco for 14 years - towards the end it was very difficult to get things done.  It used to be that if you saw a problem you could call together a team of people, explain the problem,  everyone would get on board and the team would go solve the problem. 

But once the Bean Counters took over you had to have a budget to get anything done - you could call together a team, everyone would agree that there was a problem, would agree to help you fix it, but you needed a budget. 

To get a budget you had to write up a proposal, submit it, go through multiple reviews and then submit it for the Next fiscal year's budget.   Then if you got the budget, you spent much more time managing the budget than fixing the problem.  The result - it became impossible to get problems fixed.

review_title: If you're ambitious and damn good at your job, you'll start to feel frustrated often at Cisco
job_title: Cisco Support Engineer III in San Jose, CA
pros: Since working for Cisco after graduating my growth has been tremendous. Cisco is a place where there are many experts you can learn from and gain experience especially if you're like me, someone out of school two years.
cons:
Promotions are slow and its difficult to get recognition. I am lucky in that my manager and I have a good working dialogue and I know he is listening to my concerns. 

If you're ambitious and damn good at your job, you'll start to feel frustrated often at Cisco. Reason being promotions are slow and those who are the lowest performers are rewarded by keeping their job and those who are worth their salt aren't promoted fast enough. Of course, I'm sure this is common with large companies. 

In my opinion, Cisco needs to recognize fresh talent quickly, give them (me) opportunities to grow and responsibilities, and promote them quickly.

review_title: Review by a San Jose based SW Engineer
job_title: Software Engineer III in San Jose, CA
pros:
Good benefits package
Relatively stable
Broad range of technologies one can work on
Usually, work load not too bad (but it hugely depends on which part of Cisco one's with)
cons: In my experience, if you're not from the right startup acquisition or the right part of the world, you may as well forget about career growth within. (So people go out and come back 1-2 yrs later and get promoted way faster than any amount of hard work within would ever get them promoted.) Likewise, from what I've seen, promotions are mostly about politics not ability or hard work.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: You get to work in a place where you are able to do home office and manage your own time in order to bring results, so teleworking, videoconferencing, and high use of online collaborative tools is a must. As an engineer you will work with the latest technology in the networking industry, and will be involved with high profile customers.
cons: As it continues to grow, it's becoming more and more bureaucratic. There are many processes in place to do almost every activity, and there's also an excess of surveys or polls to measure many of the aspects of work which is needed but when every area does this many times you spend a lot of your day just answering surveys. Lately, at the end of each FY there were major global restructurings which included layoffs, change in strategies, elimination of products/business units

review_title: Great Tech Company w/ Typical Large Co. Issues
job_title: Systems Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Work/Life balance; great work from home option; great at-home communication equipment; good benefits and ESPP program; good overall compensation and generally good people, especially the newer folks; Cisco is still a great resume builder
cons: Cisco is a huge company, so your experience will vary depending on your team and your position; Some departments & managers are great and you'll love your time there, but with the constant change and restructuring there's a good chance you'll be shuttled to different teams and management; Internal movement is difficult unless you're in the cliques; The culture and climate deteriorated during my tenure; Employees at the larger campuses seem to have better experiences; Some managers are only interested in managing up and not managing their teams; The stereotype of Cisco SEs and AMs being arrogant still holds true for a lot of the old guard

job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Iselin, NJ
pros: There are a few reasons to work here--mainly, its the work from home option. But never expect a promotion, never expect a pay raise. Everyone just pretends all is well...until you get hit with annual review.
cons: The main problem is that you would think there are internal secret training documents--there exist no such thing. Also, you are expected to do everything on your own. Training--on your own. In fact, there really is NO training except for the 1st New Hire training for NCE's. This company also has had 4 layoffs in the past 4 years. So, there is no stability. 8000+ people were laid off, this round.

review_title: Interesting work, good benefits, mediocre compensation
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
- great technology
- depending on the project, the work can be exceptionally god
- very smart and talented people
- very good benefits (health insurance, 4.5% 401k matching,  15% on ESPP)
- Industry leader and cutting edge work experience
- good work life balance
- lot of nerd lunches, tech talks are hosted and free for employees. Great place to learn
cons:
- Not best payer in terms of compensation. Pays only around 60 - 65% of best compensation in silicon valley (San Jose, CA)
- Too big a company. Redundant projects. Bureaucracy, lot of internal politics sometimes affects growth 
- lot of precesses to follow that stifles the work
- poor at rewarding the hard working employees
- promotions and salary increases are very few and super competitive
- since 2010, there are always layoffs looming over
- management in constant re-org/reshuffle mode
- lot of long timers (10 year+) who don't work much and are liability to the company
- their definition of R&D is buying companies who have done some good R&D

review_title: No Growth but good benefits and work-life balance
job_title: Business Development Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
* Work-life balance, benefits, gym, Child-care (bright horizons one is fantastic)
* If you are smart you can align yourself with the smart ones and learn quite a bit
* Every project is global in nature 
* Technology - global cell phone access, global weber access, ability to work form anywhere culture
cons:
* Pay, pay, pay.... especially if you are a long timer... no increments unless you threaten to quit and bring a offer
* You will stagnate once you enter, so consider quitting and coming back as the only way to get promoted and get a salary hike
* Politics ...Politics...Politics .... some of the worst people i have worked with many lacking ethics
* Absolutely NO promotions but your management will lie about it... so don't go with that expetation 
* some VP's openly admit that they follow the burn and churn policy
* No respect for the individual's career

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milpitas, CA
pros: Large corporate for better or worse. There ample opportunities to move in between divisions in the company and by and large there is job stability assuming you are not in the bottom 10% or in the wrong business unit. In one of the divisions I worked at, the product management people were smart, motivated and very friendly group of people. I also received quite a bit of responsibility and autonomy in my day to day job. That said, that was not the case in the first division I was at.
cons: It's a big company...Priorities change quickly, managers change, etc so you have to feel comfortable with sometimes choppy waters in terms of focus and direction. Senior management many times seemed more preoccupied building their own walled garden than broader collaboration within the company. Lastly, I was not impressed with the quality of engineers and organic innovation. By and large, this is a sales driven organization rather than a product/engineering driven organization.

job_title: Senior User Experience Designer in San Jose, CA
pros:
The San Jose campus is huge and often feels like several small companies rather than a large on. Your experience can therefore vary greatly depending on your Business unit / Department. That said, there are some very sharp folks working at Cisco, folks you can learn from provided that put in the effort to reach out and show interest.
Depending on your field, Cisco will give you the opportunity to work on groundbreaking projects and technologies.
I found benefits and salaries to be competitive
cons:
As it is often the case in large companies, you will bump into folks content with Status Quo. They typically have held their job for many years and are not interested in change, even when shown it is necessary and beneficial. Quite often, those folks have not kept their skills up to date, giving you the impression to step back in time.
Changes in the organisation often mean changes in priorities, when they occur faster than it takes to ship a project, some of your work might be wasted.

review_title: If the Manager doesn't like you, you better change the job
job_title: Senior Consultant in Kraków
pros:
- Cisco brand
- Great company to work for
- Self-development
- Face to face customer interaction
cons:
If for some reason your Manager (especially if he is of Polish nationality) doesn't like you, there is no way for you to advance, even if you are the best in the team. Even though that's against the HR policy, they don't really care.
You have to be tough enough, otherwise you will be silenced by the Managers even if they are wrong and you are right. From my experience (as I travel mostly to other Cisco office around Europe for customer meetings) something like this doesn't happen in other European Cisco offices (such as: Germany, Netherlands, etc).

job_title: in London, England
pros:
- you can work from home.
- relaxed dress code
- pay check isn't going to bounce
cons:
- very high workload, can get ridiculous when covering for absent colleagues.
- no training.
- no annual pay rises, irrespective of performance. So each year your efforts are rewarded with an effective pay cut as inflation eats into your competitive starting salary of 5 years before!
- limited/no career progression.
- Benefits steadily cut - the joke in the offices is that soon we will have to pay for our own toilet paper.
- employees now have to pay for own broadband and mobile phones - which the company still expects you to use for cisco business - figure that one out.
- expected to be on call virtually 24 hours a day. 
- A performance review process which is laughable - break your back or sit back - no difference.

job_title: Security Architect in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Solid Pay
-  Close to technology
-  Aggressive performance driven environment
- Most co works are bright
cons:
- Work life balance was poor.  Needed to put in 60hr weeks most weeks to hit or exceed goals
-  had to manage  offshore team which required regular evening meetings and time online
-  Nepotism is common, distracting, & irritating.  You'll find that upper management can force you to hire and tutor their foreign cousins, etc.  When you work this hard, it's bad for moral for most folks to be

job_title: Senior Business Operations Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great company in regards to benefits, pay and personal development that leads to a challenging and satisfying experience. Ethics and business transparency induce pride in being part of this company, A great culture of being part of society and understanding and accepting the responsibility that goes along with that.
cons: It's a tough environment in which to work and succeed as 'status quo' doesn't really exist. Salaries are commensurate or even at the higher end of the industry; promotions to the next grade level may appear slow (only so much room at the higher pay grades ) but pay raises are fair and bonuses and stock rewards are icing on the cake. Cisco has visionary leadership and adjusts leadership roles (and sometimes personnel) to ensure the right person for the right role to meet new challenges.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco has the money to provide engineers with equipment to do their work. So if you're an engineer and loves to be an engineer and you're lucky to be in the few business units that still value your work, then good for you.
cons:
Too many Cisco Business Units (BU) waste their times in useless talks leading nowhere. My friends at Cisco in other BU report the same thing. Cisco is no longer what it used to be.

These BUs are simply rotten with politics. Managers and directors falsify their work results to please their VPs. All they care for is to be "visible" to VPs and upper-management. Care for great product quality is the least of their priority. Of course customers are not happy. Product quality has degraded a lot.

job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility and ability to rotate across different function allows learning while working and keeps you from getting stale. Also, Cisco has been generous to its employees and has gym, cafe, and health center. Till 6 years back, it used to be a really great company and very employee centric but for last few years, it is struggling to find its place and unfortunately it has taken a toll on employees and culture when priorities are constantly shifting .
cons: Layoffs every year impact employee morale and shows flawed hiring policy. Company needs to create a culture of trust and performance by ensuring that there is some stability and not constantly laying off people every year.

job_title: Technical Leader in San Jose, CA
pros:
It's a large company, so the scenario in different business units and teams can be wildly different.  In a long career at Cisco (1996-2015), I worked in many different teams.    With only a small number of exceptions, the colleagues and teams I worked with were excellent, motivated and professional.
When working onsite (San Jose), promotion path was good, career aspirations were well supported.  
Lots of money - good pay relative to industry, good benefits.
Fascinating, hard work.
Generally a lot more openness, and startup feel than you'd expect at such a large company.
cons:
Management became a bit top- and middle- heavy.  Large company problems, projects would be cancelled (usually justifiably!) later than they should have been.  Some business functions that fell across Business Units would be hard to co-ordinate.
Only ran into 2-3 bad apples in almost 20 years, which is great ratio, but it was impossible to get rid of them even though they were well identified as such.
Standard big company demotivational stuff.   But less than you'd expect at such a large company.

review_title: Employees love the Environment, Employer love to fire...
job_title: Software Engineer III in Bangalore
pros:
Great Environment (in terms infrastructure, facilities, policies, resources, opportunities with in organization,  Trainings for self learning (not from project),  employee benefits etc).

Employees love to be part of the organization.
cons:
Only one con is management - more elaborated below....

1. No regular/proper hikes. If you want proper hike, you need to switch divisions at regular intervals. You are not important to your division.

2. Layoffs (2 cases: Either you( or your division) are not doing good or if some top level management  guy makes some crap decision. Long term survival is difficult.

3. Top management expects too much profit margin from projects(60%), doesn't respect customer needs. Management decisions effect a lot division business, which results in shutting down of division. Be smart to predict these and move to some other division or company....

4. Very frequently buy other companies without proper reasons, burn hands, and shutting them.

5. Less innovation. 

Note: There may be exception for few divisions (which are doing good).

review_title: Cisco culture degraded after Chunk Robbins' taking over
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
We can meet many talents (may be old ones) here. Overall legacy benefits are still good enough in this industry (at around, or a bit above average).
If you can lock high position/salary, you shall take it.
cons:
After Chunk took over 2 and half year ago, he only give regular employees 2 times of promotion/salary increasing. First interval is 12 months, 2nd interval is 18 months.
In John Chambers' time, this interval is 6 months. 
Normally, at Cisco, each time only 8 - 15% employee got promoted. Even the interval is 6 months, it takes > 3 years for a regular staff to get chance promoted in average. Now Chunk make it 18 months or more, the simple calculation will tell you that each promotion takes more than 10 years in average !
So unless you are at your later stage of career and secure a top position, it's not wise to join Cisco. It's not friendly to its employees anymore. For average people,
if he/she joins Cisco now, his/her career development is stalled.

review_title: Treat your front-line customer-facing staff better.
job_title: Consulting Systems Engineer in London, England
pros: Breadth of technology - fantastic being able to get involved in new area's of technology. You know when Cisco develop more IP products, customers want to hear about them. My colleagues are great to work with - everyone is willing to help. Cisco is in every account, so it's easier to introduce new technologies.
cons: Have no life - submitting numbers on Sunday afternoon/evening. Managers emailing you while they are on holiday. Some AM's planned holidays have been cancelled. Cisco do not invest enough in employing enough subject matter experts - it's always a struggle to get resource. Personal agenda's comes first, customer comes second. I have seen numerous re-organisations, which had no benefit to the customer. The technical and sales staff too far removed from senior management - their opinions don't seem to count. Poor managers get promoted, not sacked.

job_title: Marketing Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Opportunity to contribute to large scale technology transformation with a market leader. 
Highly diverse and very smart employees
Great learning environment as long as you take charge
Cash rich company who can have a huge impact...if they can figure out a bold strategy with innovation at the core.
cons:
Cisco is famous for slow and obtuse promotion processes. Young, high achievers leave.
Though promotion is a major challenge, financial rewards for top performers can be good. 
Innovation tends to be through acquisition rather than organic. If you have disruptive ideas, leave Cisco,  then position to be acquired.

job_title: Product Sales Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros:
Nice people to work with
Minimal office politics
Great Benefits as well as on-site work out facilities and cafes
Company is genuinely 
Flexible for working from home
Cisco does a lot to get their employees excited about working there
cons:
Only 2 salary increases over 8 years - we had our wages frozen while CEO got his doubled 
Trying to get commission payment is a nightmare - I consistently had to open help cases to try to figure out why I wasn't getting paid for what i sold.
It is a massive enterprise with all the waste and slowness of government
Ideas given up the chain go do get heard, but action is often too little too late when something does happen
I spend as much time navigating internal waters as I do selling
Some days I get the impression no one knows what is going on
Quotas are not given out until the end of Q1

review_title: Cisco Systems at a Cross Roads
job_title: Systems Engineer in Middletown, NJ
pros: Great Place to work, lots of options with regard to products, teams, locations. Great benefits too.
cons: Sometimes too big for it's own good.  Lots of overlapping products competing with each other. Looking to revamp itself as a subscription based software company ( understandable), but at the at the expense of massive layoffs of people that have dedicated their careers to Cisco and have survived many such transitions in the past.  This often seems to target folks they think make too much money, are not in a growing line line of business, etc.  We all get the need to right-size periodically, but there are less drastic means to do so.

review_title: TAC is great to learn in depth at okay pay
job_title: Technical Consulting Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
-Become an expert at a product/technology/platform
-Management is supportive of your career ambitions (within the company or outside)
-Work with and learn from some of the smartest people in the industry (I can't walk more than 30 steps without running into a CCIE)
-Opportunities to learn other technologies from internal training and bootcamps
-Flexible with taking off early for appointments (as long as not during your queue time)
cons:
-Limited number slots for promotions/raises, and promotions/raises happen once a year
-TAC pay is not great (Cisco is a sales organization, and thus the money is in sales)
-Long line of people for Technical Leader positions, can take years before you are considered (even if you have been operating at that level for years)
-Can be difficult to convince upper management to allocate more reqs, teams can drown and become heavily demoralized before reqs are approved (and take even more time to hire the right person)
-Older companies such as Cisco can be heavily political

review_title: This is the best company in the world! Hands down, No questions asked!
job_title: CSAP
pros:
- What I can only describe as the "Cisco Heartbeat". From the minute you start at Cisco, you start to feel part of something bigger. We are one united global team.  At Cisco we train hard and push each other to drive business success, so we have the privilege of giving that success back. We are on a mission to impact 1 billion lives globally, and I know thats only the beginning.
- Cisco is a world class company, and an industry leader in networking technology.
- As big as Cisco is, they provide each and every employee with the tools and support they need to truly be the best version of themselves.
- Hands down the best office culture I have ever experienced.
- Incredible benefits for all employees
- We have a ping-pong table in the office
cons:
- It may seem biased but I have no cons about Cisco...
- The interview process is VERY TOUGH compared to other companies, but it is only to find people who are driven enough to do great things in this world.

review_title: Good and Bad, depends on what is important to you
job_title: Manager Finance in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible work culture, Can work from home regularly. Benefits such as 401K and bonus are very good. Can move internally, i had 6 jobs in 11 years.
cons:
Very complex org going through changes. Lack of transparency on how promotions are given out promotions. Those who get promoted do not get any new responsibilities and in the subsequent annual reviews you get dinged for not performing at a level higher than earlier.
Cannot blame the people managers as people are graded on a curve and managers are forced to follow directions from VP down.

review_title: Solid Company but dealing on it's past successes
job_title: Project Manager II in Morrisville, NC
pros: Cisco has an impressive amount of talent and an excellent portfolio of products. They are great at selling their services, software, and hardware.
cons:
Cisco relies too much on it's past successes and doesn't seem to be doing anything currently to successfully to maintain their position. Also, the company has grown beyond a start-up but still maintains that they have a "start-up mentality". This is wishful thinking. There is a huge amount of bureaucracy an inefficiency as with any company of similar size. Also, they are very big on talking about work-life balance but the reality is: If you want to be a good Cisco Employee, you are expected to live and breath Cisco.

Some are o.k. with that and there are opportunities to succeed. However, if Cisco doesn't start moving to create new, exciting products and reclaim their efficiency and speed of development, the company will continue to lose it's market position and it's reputation in the industry will continue to degrade.

job_title: Sales Engineer in Amsterdam
pros: This review concerns the Sales organisation. Cisco offers some great opportunities for engaging with top clients in a broad range of technologies. Although some claim work culture is tough, I can't agree with that: it may be demanding, but there is room for initiative and good initiatives get rewarded in a fair manner. Working culture with collegues is informal and pleasant. For sales engineers there are many opportunities for ongoing learning on new technologies.
cons: Being a large gobal company it is very top-down oriented.  there is little room for strategic initiatives within the country organisations. If you fit well in the strategic plan, you have a wonderful job, if not, there is hardly room for changing this. For account managers specifically: Cisco is strongly steering on monthly revenue commits, resulting in a rather short term vision for many AM's. Only the High Touch AM's will have the opportunity for a more long-term approach. This is something you like or don't.

review_title: Pays well, but political and not very innovative
job_title: Director, Product Management in Austin, TX
pros: Generally, Cisco pays well and the benefits are top-notch, with RSU grants, company stock purchase plan, health/dental/vision insurance, and 1-for-1 401K matching for the first 5% of your salary contribution.
cons: The environment is very political with multiple VPs jockeying to see who will rule them all and building empires. There are constant reorganizations and cost-cutting leading to yearly layoffs. It's almost impossible to get promoted unless you happen to work on whatever is the hot new product. Raises are scarce (because they add to long-term cash outlay); most "rewards" come in the form of one-time bonus or RSU grants. It's a highly bureaucratic culture that rushes from crisis to crisis without adequate strategic accountability.

review_title: used to be great, not anymore
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Jose, PR
pros:
Still some name recognition, although rapidly diminishing value
Exposure to new technologies, though not well thought out
Bonus is decent at times
Ability to work from home
Talented peer engineers
cons:
Work from home is expected (Silently mandatory), and is over abused.
Long work hours worse than start-ups without the adequate rewards in terms of potential stock gains - kind of moot since Cisco stock is stuck in a quagmire.
Gradual erosion of benefits to the point of penny pinching leading to loss of morale.
Steady deterioration in health benefits to the point that health benefits at start-ups are better.
Managers and Senior management are getting fat over the backs of engineers.
The pulse survey is a joke and exists only to meet some ISO 9000 audit.
Not a good place for an engineer over the long term.

job_title: Account Manager in Richardson, TX
pros:
Flexibility to work from home is a tremendous plus. 
Do enjoy working with and for my customers.
cons:
Limited opportunities for women in many areas. Cisco talks the talk but doesn't walk the walk. Many older male bosses or leaders pretend to support women in public but in actuality are either disparaging, talk over you or just ignore you. 
Layoffs every year cause panic and discontent.
No raises - even if you work very hard and accomplish much and your reviews are consistently high, the pay increases are just not there. Better negotiate a good starting pay because spending a long time at Cisco, does not reward strong talent. 
CEO receives an 80% raise yet excellent/outstanding employees are given minimal or no raises.
Yearly reorganizations but no opportunities. Employees remain in their jobs for years and even decades because there is nowhere to go!  Management just shuffles people around and most times, it's difficult to understand their reasoning.

job_title: Solutions Architect in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: I've been working at Cisco for 8 years. As a woman, the work flexibility I have to manage my work along with my family needs has been a key reason that I love my job. As I am coming to the end of raising two children, I can look back and feel proud of what I was able to do for Cisco and for my family. The work is always challenging and I have been given almost endless opportunity to use my skills and experience to add value to Cisco. I have been consistently well rewarded for my work, and I have never felt that my gender was a hinderance in what is often considered a male dominated industry. In fact, there have been many opportunities presented because I am a woman, as Cisco takes it's commitment to diversity of all kinds very seriously and they put their money where their mouth is.
cons: As with any large company, there are some disconnects that exist in strategy and approach alignment, but I believe this is very difficult to completely overcome in any large company.

job_title: Customer Success Manager in Sydney
pros:
Cisco has a strong brand for good reason, our technology creates the industry benchmark.
Cisco encourages innovation, and as a result we are continuously improving and creating relevant products & solutions across vertical industry & market segments.
Collaboration is encouraged, and making use of the tools allows the individuals the flexibility of managing our personal lives, whilst still being inspired to overachieve in this highly competitive business.
The learning & exposure opportunities are endless, and in the right markets there is a huge opportunity to grow.
Cisco has exceptional leaders, creating a solid vision, where the technologists can innovate, and the sales & engineers can expect the technology to work as expected.
cons: The expectations on achieving sales objectives can sometime be ruthless, and having one bad year could compromise your role in the company.  The trends of constant restructures & reorganisations is negatively impacting on the employees moral.

review_title: Women in Technology - Great place to be!
job_title: Account Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: This company is by far the best company I've worked for, and I've been in the technology industry for 20 years.  Our leadership is strong and diverse, and the amount of visionaries that lead the charge on technology is amazing!  Working for an industry leader across multiple technologies/verticals gives you insight into the macro environment, rather than just little niches of a challenger brand.  Compensation is on par, and financial benefits (ESPP, stock options, 401k) are excellent.  The company also has a heart -- and puts its money and time where its mouth is.  Volunteering is encouraged, and the opportunities are endless to give back to the community and the world (and in ways that are important to YOU).
cons: Being in sales, it can be all-consuming, but 'work-life integration' is possible.  One has to be comfortable with change -- as "sameness" isn't an adjective that I would use to describe the environment.  The organizations change and shift very dynamically to adapt quickly to the marketplace and to demands on the business.

job_title: Account Manager in London, England
pros: Cisco is a great name to have on your CV. Represents a good opportunity to meet lots of big customers and do some big deals.
cons: This is one arrogant company. The general view is that we should feel very lucky to be here, and that staff are expendable. There is no real opportunity to progress, you can only get on by sucking up to the right people.  Praise for doing a good job does not exist.  The company is making the job as hard as it can in a tough environment, in the hope that people walk, as they have over recruited already and don't want to make people redundant. UK management team are not industry leaders, just yes men to the US and only understand management metrics for monitoring staff. The people who have been doing a good job successfully for years get over looked and taken for granted, while the self promoting "connected" brown nosers get promoted. Was once good, now like every other big slow arrogant beast.

review_title: A case of too many chefs spoiling the brew!
job_title: Marketing Manager in North Sydney
pros:
- Leading-edge web conferencing facilities and systems
- International exposure (work in virtual teams)/ Can have easy access to international expertise
- Diversity and generally very good people to work with
cons:
- Contractors do the bulk of 'full-timers' (FTE) 'dirty work'
- Full timers not wanting to roll up their sleeves. 'Outsources' all the work they didn't want to do.
- Lots of inefficient systems and internal business processes (a simple business process can take 20 steps to complete. Operates like a government. Nobody seems to care how 'difficult' business processes are.)
- Organisational structure is soooo confused (lines of reporting are not very straightforward). Possible to work in the same country with other colleagues but no 'allegiance' to country (field) objectives.
- Lots of budget wastage. Money not going to the right departments. All 'politically distributed' instead of based on ROI. 
- Lack of 'accountability' for full time employees on how they spend/invest money

review_title: Great place if you can find your niche
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
-Great community of people
-Several compelling areas to work
-Good support for developers 
-So many mergers and acquisitions that there is always an influx of new talent and technology

If you are looking for a place to begin a career and are looking for a stable, corporate-type job, Cisco is perfect. They have a great community and support system, but there is no mistaking the environment for a start-up. I joined out of college and learned quite a bit before deciding to pursue my MBA, so I think it can be an interesting first step in a career.
cons:
-Not great at placing people in the best position all the time.
-Lots of bureaucracy involved in generating and following through on ideas. 

While I joined as a recent college grad, most people at Cisco are in the latter half of their careers. This limits some of the entrepreneurial spirit and stifles some of the more creative ideas. There are pockets of innovation, so if you find them you can really thrive. Just don't expect that to be the norm.

review_title: Still a world-class company, but struggling to get to grips with its size
job_title: Global Operations Senior Manager in London, England
pros: Some excellent people, immensely talented, committed and hard-working.  Demanding environment, with continuous challenges.  I've never had a dull day in 13 years working for the company.  There are still opportunities for international assignments, but becoming more challenging than in the past. Compensation and rewards are good, depending on level.
cons: Company still too corporate focused in spite of its global remit.  There is a need for a massive change management exercise to bring the culture to be more process orientated, and for decision-making to be more objective.  Too much change ordered from top down but with ineffective change management below VP and even Director level.

review_title: Good place to work, but you may get fired anytime!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
-Good Salary
-Good Campus
-Good Work-Life Balance
-Good Benefits
cons:
-Management is ruthless, may shut down teams and divisions if it doesn't generate enough revenue.
-Acquire and Fire Policy
-May not have salary hike every years. (No hike from past 2 years)
-Your immediate manager decides your rating, bonus, hike and everything. No peer review or reverse review. This may not be a good thing if you and your manager arent in good terms.

review_title: Cisco great company, in great market
job_title: Business Transformation Consultant in Hudson, OH
pros: IMO Cisco is positioned as the number 1 company in the world in IT.  We have innovative products across the spectrum of IT infrastructure - data center, collaboration (i.e. phones, webex, business video), networking (route/switch) and security.  It is a constantly growing, dynamic company with great leadership.  It gives back and does the right thing.  A very high integrity company.  We have great work flexibility and are able to leverage the best collaboration tools in the world to stay connected and aligned with our mission.  We provide strategic solutions that can help solve business challenges of all companies around the world - i.e. speed, agility, flexibility, productivity.
cons: It's a big company.  With that there is a degree of complexity to the business.  Some of our services business is a bit more difficult, giving our historical "box selling" orientation.  But that is changing a lot.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sydney
pros: Cisco is a progressive and innovative environment to work in. There are opportunities to challenge the status quo and the freedom to make your role the way you want it to be. It is a very supportive environment where employees are looked after.  I feel that my skills have grown a lot working here.  One of the greatest benefits is the trusted environment which allows flexible working.  As a mother of 4, which a 1 year old going back to work full time after maternity leave, this has been a great benefit. Like anything, this is built on trust and high expectations of high quality work being met. It doesn't get boring, there is constant change.
cons: Like any large company, there are politics and levels of bureaucracy. This can be very frustrating, but it's hard to find any larger organisation where this does not exist to some degree.

job_title: Finance Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Company performance and bonuses have been strong in recent years but showing signs of slowing.
cons: Constant disruptive change - everyone is new to their role so no one really knows what they are doing.   You have to be very politically savvy to succeed and being good at the details of your job can be more of a detriment to your career path than a benefit.   Lots of opportunities at a  entry/staff level but a huge bottleneck at the management level means good talent eventually has to either leave the company, move out of finance to operations (every VP has their own "Strategy" team to self-promote), or stagnates and risks falling victim to one of the nearly constant restructurings.  24/7 work culture can make it very difficult to take PTO and easy to burn out.

job_title: Corporate Counsel in San Jose, CA
pros: Stability (its not going anywhere), opportunity to work remotely, and the potential for professional growth.
cons:
At some level, the emperor has no clothes.  This is from a non-sales, support function perspective.

Compensation model for non-sales personnel was consistently below market, and there was a polly-annish devotion to stock options.  Who remembers "The drive to 35?"  Unwillingness to recognize that it had become a large-cap, slow-growth company, and needed to move from an options to a restricted stock model. 

Managers have too much control over review process, and there is too little emphasis on rewarding talent in a fair and consistent manner.   Perception is much more important than reality -- e.g. review process too focussed on peripheral "initiatives," rather than  business results.  

Inconsistent messages  -- selling the world on telecommuting, but making it difficult for your own employees to do it as well.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Bangalore
pros:
Good flexibility,
 WFH option, 
Nice Campus and good volleyball and Pool tables.
cons:
Lot's of politics 
promotion doesn't depend on performance all about politics.
Managers are not really deserving candidates.
I feel 80% of cisco india managers are the mangers who spent 10Yrs or more in cisco. so mgmt they got by staying so long not by ability.  They got lot's of shares 5-10 yrs back and they will never dream to move out of cisco. 
People who know how to play dirty politics can grow very fast.
I've spent 6 yrs in cisco and i don't know who is HR and what they work for.
You can't complain about a manager to the top because your director will always support your  manager i know people who finally left the organization coz they complaint about the managers.

review_title: Was a great place to work until they started shuffling jobs overseas in droves, then it lost its sparkle.
job_title: HW Manager in Boxborough, MA
pros: Compensation, benefits are very good.  Performance based equity.  Work time is flexible.  Component vendors will bend over backwards to get their product designed in.  Engineering staff is top notch.   Good people to work with.   HW design tools are best avail.
cons: HW engineering a dying breed at Cisco.  Focus is on SW feature delivery.  SJ is the center of excellence and the remote US locations are just support sites.  Development teams are global - expect late night conf calls with china, india, malaysia.  Internal support of design tools is weak.  Layoffs have become a way of life.  Morale has dwindled.

review_title: Top heavy management without clear direction and limited resources set up for failure
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Name recognition on resume.  If you can get approved for work at home from a manager it's a nice perk.
cons: THEY CLOSE FOR TWO WEEKS AROUND CHRISTMAS AND NEW YEARS - employees must use vacation time to get paid and contractors don't get paid at all - Apply for unemployment in CA and it can get approved.  They plan to cut $1,000,000,000 in 2011/2012 and 10,000 people.  They bought and dumped companies.  John Chambers should GO - NOW!!!  He's driven the company down the tubes too long.  Look at their stock price from 2010 to now.  What a loss for every employee.  Moral is really hurt.  They allow incompetant managers to remain.  A lot of good talent has already jumped ship and more to follow.  Overworked with a very poor onboarding process.  Departments don't have common process and a lot of confussion between teams.  WebEx is like another company altogether although they are part of Cisco.  Products are falling behind.  Manufactureing is week with a lot of product delays.

review_title: Use to be the best place in town
job_title: Director in San Jose, CA
pros:
- ability to work any where any time
- quality of the people
- internal IT
cons:
- senior mgt is stale (external people need with different perspectives)
- annual layoffs (politically based decisions - often not based on performance or the business)
- span of control is poor which slows down execution (to many VPs/Directors versus individual contributors)

review_title: Overall-good people, just bad director/VP level. Lack of innovation and leadership development!
job_title: Change Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Decent benefits, smart people to work with.
cons: Not innovative anymore. Always trying to keep up with the next best thing and falling behind constantly. Constantly throwing good money after bad. Doesn't learn from past mistakes and doesn't invest in building real leaders. So many people promoted to VP who do not have the skills to manage people. C-Suite out of touch with what is going on beneath them and live in a bubble. Laying off good people left and right which disrupts morale.

review_title: The Best Days at Cisco Have Passed
job_title: Systems Engineer in Boxborough, MA
pros: Decent people, Flexibility (work from home), Benefits, Always learning something new, Never bored, Worldwide collaboration.
cons: Zero job security or respect - layoffs and frequent outsourcing, infrequent  raises, many technical positions not universally recognized but are only valuable to Cisco, 24/7 work, reactive management who don't stick up for their reports and are afraid to escalate issues upstream, stressful panic every end of quarter to micromanage all production support activities in order to meet quarterly earnings.

review_title: Great legacy, still good people, need to broaden and modernize
job_title: Senior Director in San Jose, CA
pros:
Incredible engineering depth in many areas -- obviously more true in networking related products, but there are very strong people in many parts of the company. 

The engineering / product side (CDO) is a kind place - they legitimately try to do the right things the right way.

Most senior management (SVP and above) is very competent.
cons:
Promotion and growth opportunities for the rank and file are too few, with forced stack-ranking creating dis-incentives to the largest proportion of engineers (who are not deemed top 10%).

Constant spin-in process for new and next-generation platforms from a very small cadre of (admittedly very talented) folks leads to morale issues in teams left to focus on legacy platforms.

review_title: Great company if in the correct organization, and or program.
job_title: Business Operations in San Jose, CA
pros: Challenging if in the correct group and, or project. Opportunity exists to learn about global business and current industry trends an challenges impacting long term global expansion and corporate sustainability. There is much groundbreaking initiatives on the radar or in progress and an willingness to do it right. Sense of urgency is present regarding these efforts and within the LOBs associated to the work.
cons: Bloated. Not everyone is doing their bit. Significant passing the buck, and for every achiever, there are multiple non achievers. A significant degree of complacency, which includes biding time for longer term employees. People are staying for the wrong reasons, sapping energy and motivation of those that care. Too many contractors with core knowledge covering for SME roles. Allows the FTEs/SMEs ability to cruise and internal business knowledge is being diluted.

review_title: Fast Paced, Good People, Fair Pay, Positive Experience
job_title: Marketing Management in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco hires solid performers. Most employees seem to have type-A personalities and are very results focused. For a big company, this is a fast paced environment. Compensation is good: bonuses historically have been generous and it's the same for restricted stock grants for more senior employees. Cisco is focused on innovating and leading in their respective areas.
