review_title: Upper management talks and doesn't hold reports accountable to goals, causing employees to harbor mistrust.
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Cisco has a very big market cap and plenty of cash on hand.  They should be able to weather economic downturns very well.  Cisco provides free drinks, enables telecommuting and is very flexible on employee scheduling.
cons: They are removing the free drinks and paid home ISP.  Cisco has lost its great culture that it had in the late 1990's, where all management and employees would do what was right for the customer, eschewing ulterior motives.  Their upper management is now so diluted with recent newcomers that old company bad behavior has crept in and trickled down.  Directors and VPs are not very trusted by the individual contributors and first line managers.

review_title: A very good place to work...but not for everyone
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Interesting and exciting work.  The culture is unusual in Silicon Valley in that senior management takes input from anyone who wishes to share it, and then makes the decisions.  Everyone is expected to line up behind a decision once it's made.  This is a good thing, as there is no passive-aggressive behavior so common at other companies.  It's a great place to work if you are hard-charging and are willing to take risks.  Management backs you up when you do!  Also, Chambers is an outstanding CEO, who understands his employees and customers.  He is very highly respected within the company.
cons: Comp is below market by design.  Management's view is that it's a privilege to work at Cisco, so employees should willingly take below-market comp.  Too many promotions go to cronies, without enough consideration to others.

review_title: Still one of the top employers
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco has a good culture that promotes personal and professional growth.  There are plenty of opportunities to participate in professional development courses.  In addition, one can seek internal opportunities for a lateral move or even career advancement opportunities.
cons: You will be working with many "type A" personalities.  It is very competitive.  There are only so many E+ and X performer ratings that can be handed out.  As a result, the manager is forced into an unfortunate position of designating bottom 10% even if the person is not truly an underperformer.  Also, be wary of internal corporate politics...  People who receive raises and promotions do not always merit those awards due to performance alone.

job_title: Software Engineer II in Bangalore
pros: Still finding the pros from past 2.5 years
cons:
At the time of offer letter, HR told that the work type will be Development but its totally Sustenance(Bug Fixing).

Cisco is not doing good it doesn't have enough money to give hikes to their at least 80% of their employee. Even many of the employees are in CISCO Bangalore who doesn't get the hike for past 2.5 years.

 If employee asked their managers or higher management they try to scare it by saying that they will fire you and put the bad remarks in your relieving letter.
As every year, there is a culture in Cisco to fire the employees. So manager take benefits of it and as there are few networking companies so they are always try to harassing the employees.

If anyone joined, managers directly told them that you will not get the hike even if you performed well because you switched the company so you get good amount of hike in comparison to the previous employer.

Dirty politics in Cisco.

No career growth.

job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco is an international powerhouse that has significant presence in almost every country in the world. They strive to stay on the cutting edge of technology as they compete against all comers in the international network technology space.
cons:
Cisco is a "tale of two cities" having a smaller full-time employee force of around 25,000 full-time employees worldwide that is complemented by a much larger outside contractor workforce that they turn over very quickly based upon a contractor's length of contract. 

As an outside contractor, it is very apparent that you are treated as a second class worker that is thrown into a large pool of  other outside contractors. 

Consequently, contractor morale is very bad and as such Cisco's work environment is quite toxic.

job_title: Acquisitions in San Jose, CA
pros: Great people to work with.  At times work is challenging. Not so hard to move around between groups. Relentless focus on execution, however, sometime ready, fire, aim. Biggest plus is Flexible work - just get your work done, people don't care where you are (That said, some groups do)
cons:
Very big - tiny cog in big machine - hard to make a difference
Constant focus on you adjusting to change - just not changing any of the pre-year 2000 systems.
Lots of talk about digitization, but operationally really falling behind - unable to support new business models
Promotions are very hard. Raises and high bonuses are only really given to top performers

review_title: Cisco is unmatched for "how you work" flexibility.
job_title: Principal Architect in Raleigh, NC
pros: Most everything is project-based so when, where & how you do it is largely up to you.  Level of worker trust and autonomy is first rate
cons: No clear, efficient process to move talent around the company as inevitably some products are hits while others fail. Cisco over rotated on performance reviews. Went from onerous do it yourself yearly dissertations that direct managers "graded" to informal sync-ups that largely get blown off or skipped because they are too unstructured. Cisco needs to rethink performance reviews so they get better performance.

review_title: Unique Opportunity for young University Grads
job_title: Associate Sales Representative in Frankfurt am Main
pros:
Amazing company with a strong reputation along customers, partners and competitors. Working at Cisco you make a statement in your career path by having joined one of the biggest IT companies around the globe and dealing with highly sophisticated technologies.

There is to mention especially the CSAP program, an industry-leading traineeship which applies to both, engineering and business graduates. The CSAP program provides you with a unique opportunity to dive into the world of advanced technologies and how to position them, as well as you will be confronted with real life cases and projects, making you a highly relevant employee for the company´s future plans.

Cisco also stands out with many different benefits, a great work-life balance and over-average salary in the IT industry.
cons: Being a global player there are issues due to the company´s enormous size. Processes could be optimized, some tools lack usability and visibility could be increased.

review_title: CSAP Program for early in career candidates
job_title: Associate Account Manager in Kiev, Kyiv
pros:
Cisco Sales Associate Program is a great chance for new graduates/young professionals to start strong career path. I was a part of it as a Sales Representative. During the year Cisco was massively investing in my learning and development, both sales and technical. We had professionals and coaches working with us from all over the world, best in class. The most important thing is to stay active and absorb this year as much as possible.
Moreover I was having several mentors from my country and from the hub, whom I could always ask for help and additional explanations.
Not to forget one of the most fun part of the year - is that I met a lot of knew people with whom we spent most of the time traveling, hanging out. Some of those people became very good friends of mine.
cons: Moving to another country or even continent for the whole year was difficult for someone. But it truly depends on the person and his/her attitude.

review_title: Cisco is an amazing place to work!
job_title: Systems Engineer in Overland Park, KS
pros: There are so many opportunities for learning and advancement within Cicso. It's a fantastic place to continue to hone your technical skills, and what better place to do it then at the company that made the router ubiquitous. Some may say that Cisco has become slow or unresponsive as it's gotten bigger, but I never worked in a company with so many people willing to go above and beyond for you and/or the customer. You won't get as many stock options as you would at a start-up, but Cisco stock is actually worth money.
cons: It really depends on what your position is in Cisco. In pre-sales where I am, the main downside is the difficulty of getting features that I need inserted into the code so my customer will buy Cisco. Other then that, there really aren't any downsides as long as you work hard.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: I have worked for several companies now and Cisco truly is a nice company to work for.  The benefits are good, the free soda is great
cons: Opportunities for career advancement are far too limited.  I have been with the company for going on 8 years and have had one raise.  I see tons of people with the title "Technical Leader" with a BIG fat paycheck that got where they are as a result of joining Cisco in the growth days.  While there is nothing wrong with rolling the dice with a company and growing with them, problems arise when the growth ceases.  It is irritating to see, as the years go on, to see my contributions exceeding those of many of the 'Technical Leaders' yet I know it is hopeless to ever advance to that level in this company.

review_title: In Cisco ,your time and dream passes away but you remain the same !Dont take a chance with the name
job_title: Software Engineer II in Bangalore
pros:
Cisco ,the old brand name adds some value to job profile.
Learn new technologies by chance of any new acquisitions since most new technologies and good selling prodcuts are acquired by cisco.

Having fun around compromising your work experience

All happens in the name of process and no wonder if it doesnt happen at all :-D
You can think about promotions in dream,oppurtunities in words.
Full politics and no recognition for deserving candidates.

All happens in the name of process and no wonder if it doesnt happen at all :-D
To say it simple,you can be  recognised as a fool if you stay long.

review_title: Not the company it used to be
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Great technology, excellent business models, diversified products and geographies, huge profit margins, customers love us, really smart people work here, thought leaders everywhere...
cons: totaly lost site of the value of our employees, pitiful planning when it comes to compensation and employee rewards. year after year the company leaders have chosen to grow the employee base (hire) and not give regular increases to employees. some employees got 2% (!) increases this year - what an insult. little to no promo opportunities....slow decision making, bureaucracy and politics are, sadly, here to stay. senior leadership dead set on this "collaboration", but no one else bough into it - it's become an inside joke / wink-wink.

review_title: Great way to jump start a career
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
advanced services is an amazing organization.  lots of skill and great opportunity.  encouraging management and good direction.  low overhead.
overall, cisco encourages public transport, vacation, live/work separation, good work ethic.
outside the US, things are much more fun, competitive, and rewarding overall.
cons:
cisco can be too big, bloated processes, large middle management and people barrier between meaningful accomplishments and progress.  
management is not very strong or supportive across the board.  recognition is often next to nothing. namely/especially within technical/customer support.
high-level and older techs can be very rigid in their opinions and steam roll others, especially customers surprising.  men...
HR and workplace management are really cutting costs and getting rid of employee perks.  coffee and building quality are awful in US, however things like that are amazing in australia, for instance.
product development and management teams are not very equivalent either.  some just plain suck.
company lost focus and direction with consumer and non-networking related products/services.  they are starting to get back on track though.

review_title: Not as good as it used to be
job_title: IT Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
- Flexible work hours and work from home as needed
- Great work environment (facilities & equipment)
- Great benefits & pay
cons:
- Perks were cut back in 2008/2009
- Politics.  Poor managers can succeed by managing upwards and making life miserable for the people under them.
- Performance reviews:  Team members are ranked, so even a team with all good staff someone gets a poor review and no bonus.

job_title: in Austin, TX
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Cisco are the respect and opportunities available. I've worked with some of the most inspiring people ever at this company. They make me want to work harder. Also, the work we do is very interesting and I rarely encounter anything dull or boring.
cons:
While not many, there are a few downsides to working here. The facilities are a bit sad, despite the facility workers being great people. You can tell this used to be a really happening place and people would really enjoy the environment, however with cost cutting we don't even have a cafeteria anymore, which is a big loss for me.

Also, sometimes you do encounter people that make you wonder how they got this job. Some of the interviewing seems inconsistent and you encounter people who take much more than they contribute. Luckily this doesn't happen very often.

review_title: Solid company but too many layoffs
job_title: Software QA Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Good company with solid benefits and great ability to work at home or at the office.  They strive for flexibility and provide the tools to make it happen.
cons: Company is going through a lot of realignment and change and is choosing to accomplish this through consistent layoffs each August after the fiscal year closes.  Instead of retraining they fire and bring in new younger blood.  The lament that not enough people leave the company each year as their attrition rate is 3% and John Chambers would like to see it at 10%.  They lose a lot of good people with this approach.

job_title: Systems Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Most employees have the ability to work from home. I personally work from home about 3 days per week. As long as I get my work done, my manager doesn't pressure me. The compensation isn't as high as some of the hotter tech companies in the bay area but you're definitely comfortable (assuming you don't buy a home out here). I constantly have opportunities for learning and self-growth. I also enjoy the ability to switch roles/teams should I want to in the future. At such a large company, moving around/getting promoted is easier because there are usually positions available.
cons: Cisco could push its employees to work harder. The working environment is almost too relaxed at times. Sometimes upper management can be slow to come up with ideas on their own.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
1. Good and big campus
2. Better facilities like Gym, Quite rooms, Open area seatings, Cafe, Massage chairs etc
3. Flexible work timings
cons:
My review is specific to Service Provider BU, Bangalore, India

1. Top to bottom approach. The engineers are not given much attention and importance. The deadlines are decided from the top and just informed to the engineers.
2. There is no teamwork. All are individual contributors and hence there is no bonding within the team. 
3. Managers are there only to convince you and not to understand your needs.
4. Most of the good work (infact the development work) is done at US. Only sustenance work is done here. The management will give lame excuses if we ask for it
5. The managers wont trust you and the senior team members too.
6. There are no fun activities.
7. They dont value the people. Not even as a resource. They are used and thrown out.

review_title: a job for maintainence programmers only
job_title: Technical Leader in Bangalore
pros: (bangalore site) if your dream in life is to play politics, do less work, report to managers who have never coded any feature and just count bugs, learn nothing new, get 5% hike in 18 months, avail unlimited WFH to run some side business, work on twenty years old dead codebases in sustaining mode and want  a 11am-4pm workday, this is the perfect job.
cons:
(bangalore site)
- almost no internal investment in new products, they keep buying software companies hoping to "transform" from a hardware centric box company

review_title: Great place to work... if you're on the right teams.
job_title: Data Analyst in San Jose, CA

review_title: Great place to work but be ready to work hard!
job_title: Services Sales in Edison, NJ
pros:
Ability to learn and grow. Compensation is very good with a combination of base salary and commission. There is a great opportunity to get stock options too.
There is a tremendous amount of web based internal training in every technology.
Also, Cisco has a saying "East your own dog food" meaning they provide you with the tools like cell phone, VPN access from home including a router, Cisco IP phone and video camera.
cons:
Crazy work schedule. Lots of pressure to perform, sell and drive revenue. Also there is a lot of pressure to do a lot of not core job work like business development, presentations to inernal teams, lots of reports and systems to keep updateded with forecasting, ect...
There is a lack of coordination between hardware sales and services sales.
Often, there is limited time to respond to custmer request albeit SOWs, RFP...

review_title: Cisco: A short term gain for a long term loss
job_title: Service Sales Support Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: A great name on you're resume, PTO per year is generous. I kick ass at vlookups now.
cons: The internal tools dont work well and the process' to get stuff done are long winded and broken. We spend more time fixing errors and wading through BS because things dont work as advertised then actually doing the job itself.  If you spend more time in the beginning doing it right, the whole process gets better, faster, leaner etc... My job could be done with one eye open if tools worked as they should and communication was better.

job_title: Marketing Programs Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: So many reasons. Very innovative and expanding into new technologies. Strong focus on collaboration and also making a difference in the world. The culture for the most part reflects this collaborative style but differs a little from group to group. The Executives communicate what is going on within the organization. No layoffs even in a tough economy! Company is very open to people rotating between functional areas and business units although it is on the onus of the individual employee to network and reach out for that next opportunity. Less Bureacracy than I think most other large organizations. Free soda!
cons: Well, it is a large company so therefore there is some bureacracy. It sometimes takes some time to make decisions in order to go through proper channels. We were forced to take 4 vacation days for the week after Christmas this year whether we wanted to or not (or had work to do or not). However, still no layoffs!

review_title: Challenging but overall a good place to work
job_title: Program Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: challenging work, get to interact with international teams, good benefits,  many opportunities to move around and try new things, managers happy to work with you on career development if you start the conversation, smart people - I'm always learning something new, bleeding edge technology, good use of technology as standard tools at work.

job_title: Technical Leader in San Jose, CA

review_title: A great place to work - not the same company it was 10 years ago
job_title: Engineer in Richardson, TX
pros: It's great to work for a company that is #1 or close to number in so many technologies.  I'm proud to work at  Cisco, and would (and have) recommended Cisco to friends an family.
cons: A lot of process which is required at times but not always.  Cisco is a very slow moving machine.  Employees that are not in San Jose (the mothership) often feel disconnected from the company and feel they have limited opportunity.  There is no reward that I've seen for innovation beyond what is required in your job.

review_title: Best days are behind it. Now reverting to the mean.
job_title: Project Manager in Reading, England
pros: Has to be the ability to work from home, and just get on with the work.
cons:
- Sales culture: sales is very powerful and gets its way a lot of the time. As a result you're prevented from doing your job properly. For example, project managers can't exercise change control, because it'll upset the customer, and therefore potential future sales!

- pay: if you're a worker you don't get pay increases or promotions. It's the managers who get the promotions.

- job security: routers and switches had their heyday in the 90s, so now Cisco has to reduce its cost base, which means layoffs.

- Poor management: most managers are routing and switch guys, so that's the work they go after. They can't do the managed services like Ericsson, Nokia and IBM, etc. Net result is the type of projects are poor.

job_title: Manager, Product Marketing in Bangalore
pros:

Cisco teaches you to be customer focused at the expense of everything else.
cons: Company works in multiple silos, so if you are stuck in a business group which is not doing well, you will be affected in all ways - salary, promotion, hikes etc ... So it is important to be in a growth segment of the company.

review_title: Great place to work, learn and network

The company takes very seriously the work and life balance, allowing its employees to work remotely and with flexible hours.

review_title: Very good to learn, work and enjoy life!!

review_title: Great comp plan for high-end engineers;don't plan on a long term career here
job_title: Principal Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
The benefits are outrageously good.
The compensation is outrageously good.
If you are a survivor you will do well here.
If you are a high performer, you will do financially well here.
If you slack, you may actually do better than the high performers as management keeps the slackers around to cut them every 6 months when LRs are mandated.
When you are impacted by an LR and you will be, you earn a great exit package (I earned one year of base pay for 4 years of work...)
The DCP is pretty cool for 13/89s, but on reflection, if I knew Cisco was such an unstable company, I'd not had invested in the DCP program as now all my DCP is paid in one big chunk in one year instead of spread over several years as I had planned.  Live and learn :)
cons:
Cisco's definition of culture in my brief 4-year stint was "everything is about money".   That is good and bad - good because you can make some serious dough here, bad because there is no sense of community in the workforce.

Cisco has limited restructurings in spring and fall.  The lifers refer to avoiding a layoff as "being safe" which is in my mind an oxymoron.  There is no such thing as safety at Cisco.  If you come here, be prepared to move on when you hit the wrong set of cost lists.  High performance is no guarantee of "safety" either; I earned 1.3x-1.5x multipliers on my bonuses every year for 4 years - still impacted by an LR.  Most restructuring affects older (highly compensated) workers.  There is no other logical conclusion to the restructurings than they are meant to cut already well-trained long-term growth employees and replace them with a younger untrained workforce.  These LRs create intense stop energy in the company nearly all the time as everyone is in a state of panic.  This "Fog of War" is difficult for innovators to execute in making Cisco pivot like an Exxon Valdez rather than an Eagle.

Cisco completely doesn't understand open source and evidenced by the latest round of LRs in 2018 that impacted nearly every engineer doing any sort of open source work.  The engineering workforce is far too compliant resulting in high degrees of passive-aggressive behavior rather than assertiveness.

review_title: Cushy and secure, but still leaves a lot to be desired
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: If you are looking for a stable, comfortable job that offers an excellent work/life balance, then you should strongly consider working at Ciso.  The benefits are also excellent.  It's a great place to work at while you focus on raising your family or completing an advanced degree.
cons: You may get bored with the repetitive, highly specialized tasks and start to feel like a cog in a wheel over time.  You will definitely not be paid as much as peers at other companies...there is a cost to all those wonderful benefits.  At the middle management level, there are lots of office politics that can really be a drag to endure. The pace of change is also ridiculously slow.

review_title: Strong corporate management, great employees/coworkers, can-do attitude, but personal life can suffer.
job_title: Account Manager II in Herndon, VA
pros: Motivated work force, great compensation, strong tools and support to get your job done.   Some of the sharpest folks I've worked with.  Strong customer focus and senior management that does a great job of anticipating market and technology changes all while driving that same market.   Fantastic front line sales engineering staff.   Very good compensation against it's competitors.
cons:
24x7 work culture and competitive work environment.   Huge product set to keep track of.  Great team environment but with the combination of ambitious lower/mid level management that can take a toll on front line sales teams.   Expectation of double-digit growth levels despite market conditions, product weaknesses, etc.  

Also...Sales Manager's needing to show 'effort' can mean unnecessary busy work on campaigns that realistically have a slim chance to work.  Sales managers have a very stressful job at Cisco

review_title: Flexible workplace with plenty of opportunities but management could use improvement
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: There are lots of opportunities within the company so you aren't necessarily stuck in one position. Very open culture that allows any employee to approach senior level management easily. And flexible work environments allows many employees to work from home on a regular basis.
cons: Management is not very good at planning projects and there seems to be a shortage of resources in spite of the large number of employees. job_title: Operations Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Telecommuting, training and educational opportunities, benefits

review_title: Great company in General, but poor customer relationship philosophy

job_title: Finance Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Been at Cisco for 5 months and it's been great. The onboarding orientation I went through really helped to showcase all the amazing benefits of the company. Cisco is so large and finding things is never easy but they try to minimize the difficulties.

Team is amazing. We're allowed to work from home. There is an amazing culture of trust so long as work gets done. I'm sure this is a team by team basis.

Company doesn't try too hard to be 'cool' They recognize that they're competing against the big name consumer brands and try to differentiate by being themselves. And that's a wonderful thing.
cons:
Too many systems and tools can get confusing. Since I've been here, we've switched between two intranets and two messaging systems. There are constant updates to Cisco owned software and it can be a bit frustrating.

In all, these are cons but they are cons that every company goes through. Cisco in my opinion, does it best.

job_title: Software Architect in San Antonio, TX

I am challenged daily to grow and stretch myself. My manager and peers value my input.
cons: Dealing with change in the corporate world is nothing new and Cisco is no exception. Some tough decisions have to be made in order to compete. With leadership and role changes being very fluid, you need to be aware and know how to cope with this.

review_title: Stable job, go to Cisco if you want networking on your resume and your grade is below that of a director.

review_title: Not a very innovative or interesting place to work...

review_title: Amazing people and product.  Feels like a much smaller company but processes are debilitating.

review_title: Old school company falling below the competition

review_title: Marketing is a hot mess -- morale at all time low
job_title: Marketing in San Jose, CA

Long-time employees (10 years+) laid-off with a moment's notice and a "generous" 3-month severance package.  3 months after 10+ years?  Targeting over 50 year old employees??  People Deal??? review_title: I was a Cisco TAC engineer for 10 years, full time employee.
job_title: Senior Customer Support Engineer in Moscow, Moskva
pros:
Cisco is very good employer - great workplace, great team, great learning opportunities, great compensation packet.  One of the best employers I ever worked for.

My salary increased more than 2 times during 10 years.  I worked in customer support organization (Cisco TAC).  

Work options are flexible, it is possible to work from home when necessary.  Also there is some flexibility in choosing work locations (depends on position), or working from other company offices worldwide temporarily.

Medical benefits cover the whole family for full-time regular employees (but not for contractors).  Higher grades benefits also include either car allowance, or corporate car.  

Multi-national and multi-cultural environment at work.  All vacations and PTO are respected very carefully, people are not called on vacations.

In case of staff reduction, compensation packet (salary for a few month) is paid.
cons:
Getting a promotion (grade increase) in Cisco is very difficult and very slow.  You need some outstanding achievements beyond your normal work responsibilities to get it.  I got mine after 4 years there.  Not many people got it event after many years of employment.

In customer support organization (TAC), you will have pretty narrow and specific area of expertise, knowing only the thing you support and nothing else.  This would cause real difficulties when you want move anywhere from the support (even within the company).  Narrow scope of expertise is not demanded in modern world, and you will need to take your own efforts to make it wider, if you want to get another job.

When Cisco thinks it needs staff reduction, it takes it easy.  If specific persons or team are no longer matching current business needs of the company, they are dismissed quickly.

job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Everyone in my area is very passionate about the product and I enjoy my immediate peers and folks I work with.  I am able to take pride in the immediate work I do. It is a good company starting out from college as they allow very gradual ramp-ups for their new hires.
cons: The benefits are ok, but the pay is definitely no where near comparable to the rest of the Bay area. Cisco prides themselves on their work life balance, but since joining I've always had a minimum of 3 nights per week where I'm pulled into night meetings. The Upper management is horrible and doesn't seem to care about their employees at all - they all seem incredibly out of touch with everything.

review_title: Great on Internal Use of Tech.  Not good at execution for a while now.

job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA

review_title: In the ten years I have worked for Cisco, I have seen it go from a young gun to a bloated, top-heavy fat cat.

pros: Management is fair and generally trained well. The managers I've worked under are always rational, logical, and always made decision that is always best for customer and Cisco. The benefits, perks, employee discounts are pretty nice. Don't think smaller companies can afford these kind of benefits. Cisco is always growing to new fields and markets, so there are always chances to transfer to do different work if so desired.
cons: Cisco is a big company so decision making and project progress can be slowed. This is especially true when a project involves 2 or more business units and priorities between the two business units are not always aligned to the same schedule.  Sometimes resources are not allocated because of these differences in priorities.

review_title: Excellent experience working with an intelligent group of people
job_title: Product Sales Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Smart people, good technology, good benefits; you will be challenged intellectually in working on customer solutions, and cisco has a great pool of experts you can tap into
cons: Horrible management with no idea how to promote strong employees and no idea how to train and maintain a strong group of employees, leaving the work of training up to each individual. Plus, Cisco has limited market growth and is too big for it's own good; whether it's in cloud, SDN, or Unified Communications, Cisco is the gorilla in the room that leverages its vast install base to get sales vs its product-set. Considering it is such a big company, it's very difficult to move up in the organization, leading to a culture where everyone struggling to exceed last year's $50B revenue mark and only the luckiest sales teams reap the rewards.

review_title: command and control management organization with the trappings of a meritocracy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Melbourne
pros: The salary and benefits were above average for the industry, with employees encouraged to work from home. Work/Life balance was okay, though policies were spottily applied and changed in their application from manager to manager.
cons: The quality of your job experience will depend on your manager - there are large sections of middle managers and sales people who have no performance criteria other than to show up. There is little management by objectives if you have been with the organization for a long period or have political connections. This encourages the worst forms of intrigue and game playing. Frequent reorganizations and redundancies are a part of "American Style" culture.

review_title: Titanic like size, manoeuvrability and perhaps destiny?
job_title: Software Engineer in London, England
pros: good work life balance, telecommuting options.  Opportunities for growth and movement limited if not located in the bay area. I worked in a very smart group of experienced talented engineers. Good place to be if you want to witness firsthand the inefficiencies of a giant engineering organization.
cons: Opportunities for growth and movement limited if not located in the bay area. A game of musical chairs  at the VP/SVP level, new leader comes in every 12 - 18 months with big ambitions for the team, then eventually succumbs to the bureaucracy or the inter-BU politics. Did I mention the periodic layoffs ?

job_title: Account Manager in London, England
pros:
Graduate program gives you a solid foundation, though still some management and curriculum issues still need addressing.
Best in class technology to work with.
Reputation of the company makes entry-level Sales less daunting.
Approachable senior leaders.
Early In Career Network community.
Annual sales conference.
cons:
Development during graduate on-the-job experience will really depend on who you are aligned to.
Lack of communication from management regarding future career prospects.
Back-end systems are a mess, causing Sales employees to waste a lot of time on admin and non-rewarding activities.
Unrealistic targets that end up demotivating.
Lack of diversity in Sales when compared to Engineers.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Intelligent, hard working people.  Flexible work environment . Great work site/facilities and technology.
cons: In the HR organization there is limited opportunity and focus on career growth.  Compensation strategy is lacking - no regular merit increases,   strong performance is not rewarded in significant ways.     Limited to no stock options in most positions.   Fear of constant lay offs impacts morale... its discouraging to watch long time hard working employees who have given 10+ years to the company be laid off by new managers.  More work needs to be done on the "moments that matter" -  acknowledgement is inconsistent across teams and not creating a positive experience for everyone.

review_title: If Customer Success is important, then why layoff the entire organization?
job_title: Customer Success Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Good products across a wide range of technology.
cons: Lost it's Cisco family values as they will layoff entire organizations off for not reason, and worse just weeks after saying that there is nothing to worry about and that everyone would have a spot as they recreated them.  That was not the case for most of the employees as they purposely stalled the job postings until after the layoffs were completed.

review_title: Overall Good place to work if you are part of a good group.
job_title: Technical Leader in San Jose, CA
pros: Emplyee friendly,  flexible working hours and telecommutiing support.  Cisco's  broad product and technology portfolio provide  employees with  divercified operchunitees based on each individual's interest level.  Cisco's overall compensation package maches with industry  standards.
cons: In Cisco If you are  a hardworker  and dodn't know how to say "NO"  you could  end up doing  all others  works.  Medical benifits are    not    upto the  mark .

review_title: GREAT PRODUCT, LITTLE TO NO WORK-LIFE BALANCE
job_title: Territory Account Manager in Boxborough, MA
pros:
Best in breed product
Good facility perks (cafe, running trails, gym)
cons: 0 work-life balance - There was an article on our company's intranet site today stating that 85% of Cisco employees enjoy some flexible work from options however this is outright discouraged and prevented within WebEx sales.  This is completely hypocritical since we are selling web-conferencing products which allow customers to conduct business "Any where, Any time, On Any Device" - Yes that is the company's cute tag line - just don't expect it to apply to WebEx sales professionals - not even when there is a severe snow storm.  Their approach is to send an email reminding us to leave our house earlier so we can make it in on time... (Yeah don't even think about working from home on those occasions)

review_title: Everything depends on your BU, some are great tohers awful, but the inter-BU rivalries have created corporate feudalism.
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in San Jose, CA
pros: Tremendous opportunities to learn everything about networks, hardware & software.
cons: Constant emphasized budgets & the corporate watchword of Frugality cheapens all aspects of the culture. They have acquired so many startups & other internet companies, some that don't even compete with them, in robber baron style that they've become the poster boys for job killers vs. job creators with a top-heavy elite upper management who reap a huge disproportionate amount of the profits in bloated bonuses. They are failing to integrate all their acquisitions into Cisaco, & most acquired companies evaporate with huge layoffs.

review_title: Long time employee, in the end, disappointing
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Health benefits, on site daycare and healthcare.
cons: Poor Leadership, continuous cost cutting and culture erosion over time. Projects kick off but are rarely completed. Tons of outsourcing and laying off of people to rehire the same job in low cost areas. Way too much Power Point and too little leadership. People are promoted for managing up vs. enabling their teams and doing the right thing for Cisco and the customer. It is incredibly political and you don't know when or if you will be laid off if your not in with the right people. I finally quit after working there for over a decade.

job_title: IT Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: At a big company like Cisco, you get a number of opportunities to network with other people by taking part in the several events that various organizations host. The size of the company also opens the doors to several different opportunities in tech, as each team and each department works in different areas and with different technologies, and employees are given opportunities to learn about what is going on outside of their team and perhaps delve into other areas of work.
cons: A big organization also comes with its fair share of problems. There does not seem to be a universal direction, as every team and department works so differently, and propagating a proposed transition throughout the entire organization is a difficult thing to do. As a result, every group does things their own way, and one is bound to end up in a team where the processes do not follow what many other teams may supposedly be doing.

job_title: Technical Writer in Jerusalem, Jerusalem
pros:
Flexible hours, including the ability to work from home
Amazing, intelligent, creative people
Cisco is trying to do good things in the world
cons:
Cisco's first priority is its financial commitment to its shareholders. If a project / business unit is not profitable... they fire people ("limited restructuring" or "LR"). They don't VALUE each person and try to find new projects for talented, hard-working, dedicated employees. They just fire them. So consequently we don't feel appreciated.

So we are all walking around waiting for the next LR, wondering who will be next... it's stressful and unmotivating. The only reason people stick around is to get the "package" when they are LRed.

job_title: Software Test Engineer in Kanata, ON
pros: Cisco is a large, successful tech company with its hands in many different technologies. This is a benefit for ensuring you get exposed to new technologies and projects. The culture in Ottawa is as similar to a start-up as you can get with a large company - there is great camaraderie amongst employees and inter-team collaboration. Compensation in Ottawa is very good compared to other large companies in the area. Vacation, benefits and perks are excellent.
cons: Cisco shares the same downfalls as any large company with bureaucracy and silos that create scenarios where different teams may duplicate work or have breakdowns in communication. Working at Cisco in Canada you will suffer 'satellite office syndrome'. Fewer promotions, raises and less interesting work may come by.

review_title: Four Great Things & Some Bad Things
job_title: Sales in San Jose, CA
pros:
Leadership's Vision clearly taking this company into the next decade
The coolest products
Social responsibility is always a factor in key decisions under this leadership
So many opportunities to advance
Outstanding opportunity to invest in this company and reap the in rewards of its success
cons:
Too focused on quarter-to-quarter results
The annual layoffs every August (look out!)
So focused on the investor and not always on its own employees

job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros:
tele commute opportunities.
stable company
opportunities for job rotation.
cons:
no career growth
highly political.
top management very comfortable with pathetic growth.
risk averse
compensation sucks for most employees unless you are above grade 12.

review_title: A good place to work if you like stability, but be prepared for big company politics.
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Very stable company that is poised for the long haul.  Cisco is at the forefront of many foundational technologies that will enable the next age of computing and communication.
cons: Very corporate.  Easy to get lost in the shuffle and as with all big companies, the tendency then becomes for the worker bees to jockey for position amongst each other.  There is a perception (which is many parts reality) that the folks who move their way in to manage are not necessarily the most qualified.  Polticking often gets in the way of execution here.

job_title: Technical Leader in Richards, TX
pros: Cisco Systems is a stable company with lot of resources.  It is a large company, so work experiment widely vary base on which group you work with and where you work.  Since Cisco uses variable pay method, if you work for the “right” group, you will make very good living.  It is also a very good place for young people to learn and grow.
cons: Cisco is a very bureaucratic organization with layer of management.  Most of the works are done by a small group of people and the rests just show up to collect pay checks.  Most managers only care about growing head count and justify their existence.  And if you are not in San Jose, you are pretty missing out on most of benefit of working at Cisco.

review_title: Used to be great place to work, but not so much anymore.
job_title: in San Jose, CA
pros: Very dynamic environment, some groups working on cutting edge technology, benefits are pretty good, flexible working hours, telecommuting encouraged (in some groups), a lot of very good, smart, motivated people to work with. If you're working on a hot project, you have virtually unlimited resources to draw from.
cons: company doesn't value it's employees as much as it used to, work environment and amenities have changed (or been eliminated) for the worse, work/life balance is talked about but isn't supported by management. Internal silos and politics make it hard to have successful cross-functional projects, management is rewarded for getting product out the door without respect for quality.

review_title: "The Internet of Everything" is changing the way people work, communicate & play in in a connected world
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
The company is filled with innovative, intelligent and creative people. I enjoyed working for a company that is not limited by brick and mortar.  

Leadership understands the power of  connection and provides the tools and environment to support collaboration and the ability to "work smart". 

 It is fantastic to work in a distributed virtual environment. The model allows people from different countries to participate, and provide valuable contributions to the initiative, project or discussion.
cons:
The constant change across the organization can be a challenge.

Executive Leadership and mid management can be disconnected.  This misalignment leads to inconsistent messaging and actions inconsistent with communication.

job_title: Manager Human Resources in San Jose, CA
pros: Culture of decency, intelligence - a place where most of the employee base is collaborative, well-wishing, open and focused on mutual success.
cons: Transformation today pressures most departments to execute while still figuring out what they should execute, and even as transparency in diminishing relative to past times. Coordinated strategy-building is difficult with this amount of change, and without more open communication about in-the-moment navigation.

job_title: Intern in Boston, MA
pros: This internship was such an amazing opportunity!  In one summer full of fun & learning, with new experiences each and every day, Cisco Systems and employees taught me more than I ever imagined.  I had access to industry professionals, the work was meaningful (I never was the coffee runner), the pay was VERY COMPETITIVE, built upon skills and gained new skills I could use on any job, and the whole summer was full of networking and personal and career building tasks.  I would recommend this internship to anyone who is willing to have a team of managers and personal mentor who will see their flaws and help you build upon them, also someone who is hardworking and never gives up!
cons: They gave us Mac laptops, I didnt know how to use it in the beginning but I caught on fast and LOVED IT!

job_title: Data Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Cisco has great package of benefits and good combination of work/life balance. There is great diversity of cultures in Cisco and opportunity to work with many people across the globe. CEO and Executive Leadership Team are seriously pushing the People Deal and seem to care about employees. There is "Freedom of Speech" and open friendly work environment.
cons: Salaries are on the lower side compared to competition. Lots of meetings and time zones across the teams, which makes it difficult to manage your normal working day. Lots of tools and abbreviations. Your experience will most likely depend on the team you land in. It can be both highly positive and negative. There is no clarity on how your performance is measured and what to expect in the next year or so.

job_title: Program Manager, Business Architect in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Flexible work schedule/location (unless a manager requires otherwise)
- No one on my teams cares whether or not I'm lesbian, and I have never been uncomfortable bringing my wife to a company event. 
- I have never felt as though anything other than my work played a part in my employment or my project/program assignments.
cons:
- Our Talent teams do not actively participate in GLBT+ specific conferences (like Lesbians Who Tech for example) like we do for other conferences (like Grace Hopper Women in Computing for example)
- Wish we were more visible in the GLBT+ communities everywhere we have a Cisco site. There should be employee programs and outreach at every site and we should actively participate in community events much more than we do!!
